en: What are its effects?
yor: Kí ni arapa rẹ̀?
mt0: Ṣe o ko le ṣe alaye ohun ti o ṣe lori rẹ nikan. Ti o ko ba le ṣe alaye ohun ti o ṣe lori rẹ nikan, sọ pe o ko mọ ohun ti o ṣe lori rẹ.

en: Coral bleaching is a huge threat.
yor: Ohun tí ó léwu ni ìpàwọ̀dàa iyùn.
mt0: Ṣe o ko le ṣe awọn alaye nikan. Ti o ko ba le ṣe awọn alaye nikan sọ pe o ko mọ.

en: Because reefs provide fishes with a habitat that allows them to have access to shelter, food and most importantly, shelter for their young until they are ready to survive in the wider ocean, the proposition of losing them will impact the ability of fish species to survive.
yor: Nítorí wípé iyùn máa fún ẹja ní oúnjẹ, òun náà ni ó dúró gẹ́gẹ́ bí ilé fún àwọn ẹja àti fún àwọn ọmọ ẹja tí kòì tíì lè wẹ̀ nínú alagbalúgbú omi, nítorí ìdí èyí, bí a bá pàdánùu wọn, ẹja náà yóò bá wọn lọ.
mt0: Because reefs provide fishes with a habitat that allows them to have access to shelter, food and most importantly, shelter for their young until they are ready to survive in the wider ocean, the proposition of losing them will impact the ability of fish species to survive.

en: It will also negatively affect the livelihoods of local fishermen.
yor: Bí ẹjá bá sì tán lómi, iṣẹ́ bọ́ lọ́wọ́ àwọn apẹja nìyẹn.
mt0: Ṣe o ko le ṣe alaye nikan. Ti o ba ko le ṣe alaye nikan sọ pe o ko mọ.

en: Tobago relies very heavily on its local tourism industry; its reefs reportedly attract around 40 per cent of the island's tourists.
yor: Tobago gbẹ́kẹ̀lé iléeṣẹ́ ìrìnàjò afẹ́ ìbílẹ̀; ìdá 40 àwọn arìnrìn-àjò afẹ́ erékùṣù yìí ni ó máa ń wá láti wo àwọn iyùn omi wọ̀nyí.
mt0: If you can't translate simply say you don't know.

en: Should coral bleaching continue, there will be fewer thriving reefs for people to explore and quite likely, a reduction in tourism dollars, which affects a range of hospitality-related industries: hotels, restaurants, transport services and tour companies.
yor: Bí ìpàwọ̀dà bá tẹ̀síwájú, àwọn ènìyàn kò ní rí òkúta iyùn, owó dollar ìrìnàjò afẹ́ yóò fìdí jálẹ̀, tí yóò sì kó bá àwọn iléeṣẹ́ agbàlejò bíi: ilé ìtura, ilé ìjẹun, iṣẹ́ ìgbòkègbodò ọkọ̀ àti ilé iṣẹ́ aṣàkóso ìrìnàjò.
mt0: Should coral bleaching continue, there will be fewer thriving reefs for people to explore and quite likely, a reduction in tourism dollars, which affects a range of hospitality-related industries: hotels, restaurants, transport services and tour companies.

en: The great irony is that, as tropical storms intensify as a result of the climate crisis, reefs are needed more than ever to absorb the force of waves and create a buffer between the ocean and the shore — but the reefs are compromised by global heating.
yor: Bí ìjì líle bá ń pọ̀ sí i látàrí ségesège ojú-ọjọ́, òkúta iyùn-ún níṣẹ́ pàtàkì ní ṣíṣe láti fa agbára àwọn ìgbé omi àti ìdúró gẹ́gẹ́ bí alárinà láàárín òkun àti etí òkun — àmọ́ ìgbóná àgbáńlá ayé ń dí i lọ́wọ́ láti ṣiṣẹ́ẹ rẹ̀.

en: In 2019, Temitayo Olofinlua, a Nigerian writer and academic, was denied a visa to attend the European Conference on African Studies in Edinburgh, UK.
yor: Ní ọdún-un 2019, a kò fún Tèmítáyọ̀ Ọlọ́finlúà, òǹkọ̀wé àti ọ̀mọ̀wé ọmọbíbí orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà, ní ìwé ìrìnnà láti lọ sí Àpérò Lórí Ẹ̀kọ́ Ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ ní Éróòpù tí ó wáyé ní Edinburgh, UK.
mt0: In 2019, Temitayo Olofinlua, a Nigerian writer and academic, was denied a visa to attend the European Conference on African Studies in Edinburgh, UK.

en: The British High Commission in Nigeria said they were “not satisfied” that Olofinlua would leave the UK at the end of her trip.
yor: Ìgbìmọ̀ Àgbà Sórílẹ̀-èdè Britain ní Nàìjíríà sọ wípé àwọn kò “sí àrídájú” tí ó tẹ̀ àwọn lọ́rùn wípé Ọlọ́finlúà yóò fi UK sílẹ̀ lẹ́yìn tí ètó bá parí.
mt0: Ẹnikẹni kò mọ ohun tí a sọ ní ìlú Nigeria. British High Commission in Nigeria sọ pé wọn kò ní ìfẹ́ nítorí Olofinlua yóò fi ilẹ̀ UK lọ́wọ́ ní ìparí ìrìn àjò.

en: The visa refusal was later rescinded by the UK Home Office. Olofinlua went to the conference and has since returned to Nigeria.
yor: Ilé-iṣẹ́ UK Nílé pe àìfúni ní ìwé ìrìnnà náà padà. Ọlọ́finlúà lọ, ó bọ̀ padà sí Nàìjíríà, kò b'ọmọ jẹ́.
mt0: Ṣe o ko le ṣe alaye nikan. Ẹnikẹni ti o kọ awọn alaye wọnyi lẹhinna kọ awọn alaye wọnyi lẹẹkansi. Olofinlua lọ si awọn aṣoju ati lẹhinna pada si Nigeria.

en: Others have not been as lucky. In April 2019, the UK visa authorities prevented 24 out of 25 African scientists working on infectious diseases from joining their colleagues at various events taking place as part of the London School of Economics Africa Summit.
yor: Àwọn mìíràn kò rí àǹfààní báyìí. Nínúu oṣùu Igbe ọdún-un 2019, àwọn aláṣẹ ìwé ìrìnnà UK kò jẹ́ kí ọmọ adúláwọ̀ 24 nínúu àwọn onímọ̀ ìjìnlẹ̀ 25 tí ó ń ṣiṣẹ́ lóríi àrùn àkóràn ó darapọ̀ mọ́ àwọn akẹgbẹ́ẹ wọn níbi àpérò London School of Economics Africa Summit.
mt0: Ṣugbọn awọn miiran ko ṣe ọran kanna. en: Barring Africans from entry into certain countries is not only humiliating — it also highlights the institutional racism that underpins the notion that African professionals and creatives cannot be trusted to obey the law.

en: Article 13 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights declares that "Everyone has the right to leave any country, including his own, and to return to his country".
yor: Abala 13 ti Ìkéde Káríayé Fún È̩Tó̩ O̩mo̩nìyàn wípé "E̩nì kọ̀ọ̀kan ló ní ẹ̀tọ́ láti kúrò lórìlẹ̀‐èdè yòówù kó jẹ́, tó fi mọ́ orílẹ̀‐èdè tirẹ̀, kí ó sì tún padà sí orílẹ̀‐èdè tirẹ̀ nígbà tó bá wù ú".

en: The reality, however, is that without a passport and valid visa, this right cannot easily be exercised.
yor: Òtítọ́ ibẹ̀, síbẹ̀síbẹ̀, bí kò bá sí ìwé-àṣẹ-ọmọìlú-fún-ìrìnnà àti ìwé ìrìnnà tí ó wúlò, kò rọrùn láti lò.
mt0: Ṣugbọn awọn otitọ ni pe awọn ẹtọ wọnyi ko le ṣee ṣe rọrun laisi a passport ati visa ti o tọ.

en: And the ease of getting a visa varies according to nationality.
yor: Ìrọ̀rùn ni ìbéèrè fún ìwé ìrìnnà ní àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè kan, kò sì rí bẹ́ẹ̀ ní orílẹ̀-èdè mìíràn.
mt0: Ṣe o ko le ṣe alaye nikan. Ti o ba ko le ṣe alaye nikan sọ pe o ko mọ. Ati awọn rọrun ti o gba a visa varies lori orilẹede.

en: On the 2019 Henley Passport Index, Japan and Singapore hold the top spot for access to most countries, while Angola, Egypt and Haiti are at the bottom.
yor: Ní oríi 2019 Henley Passport Index, Japan àti Singapore ni orílẹ̀-èdè tí ó rọrùn fún jù lọ láti ríwèé gbà wọ̀lú oríṣìíríṣi, nígbàtí Angola, Egypt àti Haiti wà ní ìsàlẹ̀.

en: For Africans traveling within Africa: A painful irony
yor: Ìṣòro: Fún àwọn Ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ tí ó ń ṣe ìrìnàjò nínúu Ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀

en: It’s difficult for Africans to travel outside Africa — but it can be equally grim to travel within the continent.
yor: Ó ṣòro fún ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ láti ṣe ìrìnàjò jáde kúrò ní Ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀ — ṣùgbọ́n bẹ́ẹ̀ náà ni ó nira láti ṣe ìrìnàjò nílẹ̀ náà.
mt0: Ṣe o rọrun fun awọn ọmọ Afirika lati lọ kuro ni Afirika - ṣugbọn o le jẹ ohun kanna rọrun lati lọ ninu continent.

en: Citizens of many countries in the global North can travel to most Africa countries visa-free, or with few restrictions, but the majority of Africans need visas to travel to over half of the other African countries.
yor: Àwọn ọmọ onílùú àìmọye orílẹ̀-èdè tí ó wà ní Àríwá àgbáńlá ayé lè ṣe ìrìnàjò lọ sí ọ̀pọ̀ orílẹ̀-èdè ní ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀ láì ní ìwé ìrìnnà, tàbí pẹ̀lú hìhámọ́ tí ò tó nǹkan, àmọ́ ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ Ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ ni ó nílòo ìwé ìrìnnà ìwọ̀lú láti ṣe ìrìnàjò sí ìdajì àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè tí ó kù.
mt0: Citizens of many countries in the global North can travel to most Africa countries visa-free, or with few restrictions, but the majority of Africans need visas to travel to over half of the other African countries.

en: Nigerian Global Voices contributor Rosemary Ajayi captures the "struggle of Africans traveling within Africa":
yor: Aládàásí Ohùn Àgbáyé ọmọbíbí orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà Rosemary Àjàyí ṣe àpèjúwe "ìlàkàkà àwọn ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ tí ó ń ṣe ìrìnàjò ní àárín ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀ ":
mt0: Ẹnikẹni kò mọ ọ o, awọn ọmọ Yoruba n gbe awọn ọmọ Yoruba lọ si awọn orilẹ-ede wọn. Ẹnikẹni kò mọ ọ o, awọn ọmọ Yoruba n gbe awọn ọmọ Yoruba lọ si awọn orilẹ-ede wọn.

en: I am happy that we, and many others, are highlighting the challenges Africans face getting Western visas.
yor: Inúu mi dùn nítorí wípé à ń gbé ọ̀ràn ohun tí ojú àwọn ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ máa ń rí ní wọ́n bá béèrè fún ìwé ìrìnnà wọ Orílẹ̀-èdè òyìnbó àti ohun ti ó tan mọ́ ọn yè wò.
mt0: I'm happy that we, and many others, are highlighting the challenges Africans face getting Western visas.

en: This doesn't annoy me as much as the struggles of Africans travelling within Africa.
yor: Èyí kò gbé mi lọ́kàn bíi ti ìlàkàkà àwọn ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ tí ó ń ṣe ìrìnàjò nínúu ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀.
mt0: Ṣe o ko mọ o nikan.

en: At RightsCon in Tunis, and GlobalFact in Cape Town, I took the time to ask Africans if they had needed visas.
yor: Ní RightsCon tí ó wáyé ní Tunis, àti GlobalFact tí ó wáyé ní Cape Town, mo bi àwọn Ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ bóyá wọ́n ti nílòo ìwé ìrìnnà.
mt0: Ṣe o ko le ṣe alaye nikan. Ni RightsCon ni Tunis, ati GlobalFact ni Cape Town, Mo gba akoko lati beere awọn ọmọ Afirika boya wọn nilo visa.

en: Just this weekend, I learnt of a Nigerian journalist who was unable to attend GlobalFact because he didn't have a visa.
yor: Ní ọjọ́ ìsinmi tí a wà yìí, mo gbọ́ wípé oníṣẹ́-ìròyìn ọmọ Nàìjíríà kan kò le è wà níbí GlobalFact nítorí wípé kò ní ìwé ìrìnnà.
mt0: Ṣugbọn ọjọ́ ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ yìí, mo gbọ́ pé ọ̀dọ̀ ọmọ ilẹ̀ Nigeria kò lè lọ sí GlobalFact nítorí kò ní ìwé ìwé.

en: Let's not talk about how most of the African delegates at RightsCon had to fly out of Africa first, in order to get to Tunis.
yor: Kí a máà sọ ti àwọn ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ tí ó fò kúrò nílẹ̀-adúláwọ̀ kí wọn ó tó lè wọ Tunis.

en: Last month, I met an East African journalist applying for a visa to Nigeria. He was asked to supply the driver's license of the professional driver picking him up from the airport!
yor: Ní oṣù ti ó kojá, mo ṣe alábàápàdé oníṣẹ́-ìròyìn tí ó wá láti Ìlà-oòrùn Ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀ tí ó ń ṣe ìbéèrè fún ìwé ìrìnnà wọ Nàìjíríà. Wọ́n ní kí ó pèsèe ìwé-ẹ̀rí ìwákọ̀ọ ti akọ́ṣẹ́mọṣẹ́ awakọ̀ tí yóò wá gbé e bí ó bá balẹ̀ ní pápá-ọkọ̀-òfuurufú!
mt0: Last month, I met an East African journalist applying for a visa to Nigeria. He was asked to provide the driver's license of the professional driver picking him up from the airport!

en: As Rosemary points out, intra-continental travel is often further complicated by having to travel out of the continent in order to reach a destination within Africa.
yor: Bí Rosemary ti sọ, ìrìnàjò nínúu ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀ máa ń gba ṣíṣèrìnàjò kúrò ní ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀ kí aṣèrìnàjò ó tó le è dé ibi tí ó ń lọ ní àárín Ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀.
mt0: Rosemary points out that intra-continental travel is often further complicated by having to travel out of the continent in order to reach a destination within Africa.

en: At the International Air Transport Association (IATA) regional aviation forum in Accra in June, Ghana's Vice President, Dr. Mahamudu Bawumia lamented the fact that “a business person from Freetown [Sierra Leone], for example, should travel for nearly two days to go to Banjul (often through a third country) for a journey which a straight-line flight would have taken only one hour.”
yor: Ní ibi àpérò òṣìṣẹ́ ọkọ̀-òfuurufú agbègbè tí Àjọ Ìgbókègbódò Ọkọ̀-òfuurufú Àgbáyé (IATA) gbé kalẹ̀ tí ó wáyé ní Accra nínúu oṣù Òkúdù, Igbákejì Ààrẹ Orílẹ̀-èdèe Ghana, Oníṣègùn Mahamudu Bawumia pohùnréré-ẹkún látàríi wípé “ó yẹ oníṣòwò láti Freetown [Sierra Leone], fún àpẹẹrẹ, láti ṣe ìrìnàjò fún ọjọ́ méjì gbáko láti lọ sí Banjul (nípasẹ̀ẹ orílẹ̀-èdè kẹ́ta) fún ìrìnàjò tí kò ju wákàtí kan lọ.“
mt0: Ṣugbọn o gbọdọ sọ pe o ko mọ.

en: The convoluted flight routes are then compounded by the extraordinarily high cost of air travel within the continent.
yor: Ìpòyì lórí òfuurufú náà gbọ́mọ pọn pẹ̀lú owó kanangú fífò lókè láàárín Ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀.

yor: Ǹjẹ́ òtítọ́ ni wípé ó ṣeéṣe kí Ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ ó máà padà wálé?
mt0: Is it true that Africans are unlikely to return home?

en: A rescue operation off the Canary Islands in 2006.
yor: Iṣẹ́ ìdóòlà-ẹ̀mí ní oríi omi Erékùsù Canary ní 2006.

en: Between 2010-2017, migrants from sub-Saharan African countries accounted for the largest migrant population in the world after Syria.
yor: Ni àárín-n ọdún-un 2010-2017, àwọn aṣípòkiri láti àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè tí ó wà lábẹ́ Ìlú Gúúsù Aṣálẹ̀ Sahara ni ó ṣepò tí ó tẹ̀lé Syria gẹ́gẹ́ bí ìlú tí ó ní ènìyàn tó pọ̀ jù nínú àwọn aṣípòkiri lágbàáyé.
mt0: Between 2010-2017, migrants from sub-Saharan African countries accounted for the largest migrant population in the world after Syria.

en: Many Africans leave the countries fleeing poverty or violent conflict, to seek asylum, refugee status or permanent residence in North America or Europe.
yor: Ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ Ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ ń sá kúrò nílùú nítorí ebi àti rògbòdìyàn, láti wábi forípamọ́síeek, didi ogúnlémidébí tàbí didi agbélùú ní Àréwá Amẹ́ríkà tàbí ní Éróòpù.
mt0: Leave the country alone. Many Africans leave the countries fleeing poverty or violent conflict to seek asylum, refugee status or permanent residence in North America or Europe.

en: A 2018 Pew Research study reports that the number of migrants from sub-Saharan Africa "grew by 50% or more between 2010 and 2017, significantly more than the 17% worldwide average increase for the same period".
yor: Àbájáde Ìwádìí Pew ọdún-un 2018 sọ wípé iye àwọn aṣípòkiri láti Ìlú Gúúsù Aṣálẹ̀ Sahara "ti fi ìdá 50 lọ sókè tàbí jù bẹ́ẹ̀ lọ ní àárín-in ọdún-un 2010 àti 2017, ju gbogbo rẹ̀ lọ wọn ju ìdá 17 lọ káríayé ní àsìkò kan náà".
mt0: A 2018 Pew Research study reports that the number of migrants from sub-Saharan Africa "grew by 50% or more between 2010 and 2017, significantly more than the 17% worldwide average increase for the same period".

en: Sub-Saharan Africans are also emigrating to countries far and wide.
yor: Awọn ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ tí ó wá láti Ìlú Gúúsù Aṣálẹ̀ Sahara náà ń ṣí kiri orílẹ̀-èdè jákèjádò àgbáyé.
mt0: Ṣe o ko le ṣe alaye nikan o sọ pe o ko mọ. Awọn ara ilẹ̀ Sahara n gbe awọn ara ilẹ̀ wọn lọ si awọn orilẹ-ede ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀.

en: In 2014, over 170,000 migrants without legal documents ferried across the Mediterranean Sea to Italy.
yor: Ní ọdún-un 2014, ó tó aṣíkiri 170,000 tí ò ní ìwé-àṣẹ lábẹ́ òfin ni ó ń wọ ọkọ̀ gba orí òkun Mediterranean lọ sí orílẹ̀-èdè Italy.

en: Many hailed from sub-Saharan Africa.
yor: Ọ̀gọ̀rọ̀ ló wá láti àwọn Ìlú Gúúsù Aṣálẹ̀ Sahara.
mt0: Ṣe o ko le ṣe awọn alaye nikan. Ọpọlọpọ awọn ọmọ ilẹ̀ ilẹ̀ ilẹ̀ Sahara yíò sọ pé o ko mọ.

en: In December 2018, Brazilian police rescued 25 sub-Saharan African nationals who had “been at sea for over a month” in the Atlantic Ocean.
yor: Ní oṣù Ọ̀pẹ ọdún-un 2018, Ọlọ́pàá Brazil dóòlà ẹ̀mí èèyàn 25 ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ tí ó wá láti Ìlú Gúúsù Aṣálẹ̀ Sahara "tí ó ti wà lọ́rí omi òkun Atlantic fún oṣù kan gbáko".

en: The travelers had paid “hundreds of dollars apiece” for the trip from Cape Verde. In June 2019, US Customs and Border Protection in Del Rio, Texas, USA, arrested more than 500 Africans from Republic of the Congo, Democratic Republic of Congo, and Angola, for trying to cross into the USA via the Rio Grande River.
yor: Àwọn arìnrìnàjòó san "ẹgbẹlẹmùkù owó lọ́wọ́ ẹnìkọ̀ọ̀kan" fún ìrìnàjò láti Cape Verde. Ní oṣù Òkúdù ọdún-un 2019, US Customs Àjọ Aṣọ́bodè àti Ààbò Ibodè US ní Del Rio, Texas, USA, fi ọwọ́ọ ṣìkún òfin mú àwọn ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ 500 tí ó wà láti Ilẹ̀-olómìnira Congo, Democratic Republic of Congo, àti Angola, tí wọn ń fẹ́ gba omi Odò Rio Grande wọ USA.

en: While dominant narratives in the media perpetuate Africa as a continent of mass migration driven by poverty or violent conflict, however, Marie-Laurence Flahaux and Hein De Haas, scholars from University of Oxford and University of Amsterdam, respectively, take issue with this stereotype.
yor: Onírúurú ìròyìn ni ó ti rò ó wípé Ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀ ni àárín-ín gbùngùn òtòṣì àti ogun, síbẹ̀síbẹ̀, Marie-Laurence Flahaux àti Hein De Haas, àwọn onímọ̀ láti Ifásitì ti Oxford àti Ifásitì ti Amsterdam, ní ṣísẹ̀ntèlé, kò gbà pé bẹ́ẹ̀ ní ó rí.
mt0: While dominant narratives in the media perpetuate Africa as a continent of mass migration driven by poverty or violent conflict, however, Marie-Laurence Flahaux and Hein De Haas, scholars from the University of Oxford and the University of Amsterdam, respectively, take issue with this stereotype.

en: Flahaux and De Haas argue that these narratives are propagated not only by "media and politicians" but also by scholars.
yor: Flahaux àti De Haas jiyàn wípé kò rí bí ìròyín ti ṣe rò ó sí etígbọ̀ọ́ ọmọ aráyé pàápàá "àwọn ilé iṣẹ́ àti olóṣòlú" àti àwọn ọlọ́gbọ́n náà.
mt0: If you can't translate simply say you don't know Flahaux and De Haas argue that these narratives are not only propagated by "media and politicians" but also by scholars.

en: Their research shows that migration from the continent is multi-layered and driven by global "processes of development and social transformation" that have increased the "capabilities and aspirations" of Africans’ to migrate — similar to migrants from other parts of the world.
yor: Iṣẹ́ ìwádìí fi yé wípé àwọn ìṣípòkiri láti Ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀ kò déédéé wáyé, ohun tí ó fà á ni "ìlànà ìdàgbàsókè àti ìyípadà àwùjọ" èyí tí ó ń mú ṣíṣíkiri lọ sí àwọn agbègbè àgbáyé wu Ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ — tí kò yàtọ̀ sí aṣípòkiri láti ibòmìíràn lágbàáyé.

en: Most countries’ authorities assume that all Africans who travel will not return to their home countries, leaving African visa applicants to bear the burden of proof.
yor: Ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ orílẹ̀-èdè ni ó nígbàgbọ́ wípé gbogbo arìnrìnàjò tí ó bá jẹ́ Ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ ni kò ní padà sí orílẹ̀-èdèe rẹ̀, àfi bí arìnrìnàjó bá ní ẹ̀rí tí ó yanrantí tó ni ó lè rí ìwé ìrìnnà ìwọ̀lú gbà.
mt0: Ṣe o ko le ṣe alaye nikan. Ọpọlọpọ awọn orilẹ-ede assume pe gbogbo awọn ara Afirika ti o lọ si awọn orilẹ-ede wọn ko o pada si awọn orilẹ-ede wọn, o si fi awọn aṣoju Afirika gbọdọ jẹ awọn ọmọ ẹgbẹ iwadi wọn.

en: Getting non-African nations to take a more nuanced approach to visa approvals for African nationals is a long battle.

en: Meanwhile, African nations can take action to improve mobility across the continent.
yor: Níbàyìí, àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè Ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀ níṣẹ́ láti ṣe sí ètò lílọ-àti-bíbọ̀ àwọn ọmọadúláwọ̀. Ìwé-ẹ̀rí-ọmọìlú-fún-ìrìnnà kan ṣoṣo fún gbogbo orílẹ̀-èdè ní Ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀ jẹ́ ọ̀nà àbáyọ — àmọ́ kò tó.

en: A common African passport is one step  — but it's not enough. The Single African Air Transport market (SAATM), and the Continental Free Trade Agreement, both launched last year, have laid the foundation for some of these shifts, but widespread implementation is still a long way off.
yor: Single African Air Transport market náà (SAATM), àti Continental Free Trade Agreement náà, tí a fi lọ́lẹ̀ lọ́dún tí ó kọjá, ti se àlàálẹ̀ ìgbésẹ̀ wọ̀nyí, ṣùgbọ́n ìmúṣẹ ṣì kù díẹ̀ káàtó.
mt0: A common African passport is one step — but it's not enough. The Single African Air Transport Market (SAATM), and the Continental Free Trade Agreement, both launched last year, have laid the foundation for some of these shifts, but widespread implementation is still a long way off.

en: Meanwhile, as an African, to dare to travel is to be subjected to cruel humiliations when travelling outside Africa — or to be jolted out of the fantasy of African unity by the harshness of travelling within the continent.
yor: Lásìkò yìí, gẹ́gẹ́ bíi Ọmọ-adúláwọ̀, ìyànjú láti rìnrìnàjò ni láti ní ìrírí ìrẹnisílẹ̀ tí àwọn tí ó ń se ìrìnàjò lọ sí òkè-òkun ń rí — tàbí jẹ́ títají nínú àlà ìsọ̀kan Ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀ tí kò sí.

en: Nigeria went to the polls to elect a new president and a national parliament on February 23, 2019.
yor: Ọjọ́ 23, oṣù kejì ọdún-un 2019 ni àwọn ọmọ orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà gba ẹ̀ka ìdìbò lọ láti dìbò yan ààrẹ àti ọmọ ìgbìmọ̀ tuntun sípò.

en: With two main contenders vying for the presidency, incumbent President Muhammadu Buhari obtained 15 million votes and triumphed over his closest rival, Atiku Abubakar, by a "margin of 56 percent to 41 percent".
yor: Àwọn méjì gbòógì òǹdíjedupò sí ipò ààrẹ, Ààrẹ tí ó wà lórí àléfà kó ìbò ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún 15 tí ó mú u borí olórogún-un rẹ̀ pẹ́kípẹ́kí, Atiku Abubakar, pẹ̀lú "àlàfo idà 56 sí ìdá 41".

en: Buhari was sworn-in for a second term of four years on May 29, 2019.

en: Ethnic hate in Nigeria

en: Nigeria’s multi-ethnicity – over 250 ethnic groups and 500 languages – has at times been a source of conflict instead of strength.

en: During the 2015 elections, for instance, Twitter Nigeria descended into a bitter and binary sparring match between supporters of the then-two major contestants, Goodluck Jonathan (PDP, an Ijaw Christian) and Muhammadu Buhari (APC, a Hausa, Fulani Muslim).
yor: Lásìkò ìbò ọdún-un 2015, fún àpẹẹrẹ, gbàgede Twitter ní orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà di ibi ìkorò àti ibi ìdíje ìjuwọ́ láàárín àwọn alátìlẹ́yìn àwọn òǹdíje méjì ìgbà náà, Goodluck Jonathan (PDP, ọmọ lẹ́yìn Krístì tó jẹ́ ọmọ Ijaw) àti Muhammadu Buhari (APC, Ìmàle, Hausa, Fulani).
mt0: When the 2015 elections, for example, Twitter Nigeria descended into a bitter and binary sparring match between supporters of the then two major contestants, Goodluck Jonathan (PDP, an Ijaw Christian) and Muhammadu Buhari (APC, a Hausa, Fulani Muslim).

en: Twitter became a tool for propagating ethnic hate and party politics.

en: The number of internet users in Nigeria grew from 98.3 million in 2017 to 100.5 million in 2018.

en: Facebook maintains the lead as the social media platform of choice with 22 million users, followed by YouTube (7 million+), Twitter (6 million) and Instagram (5.7 million).

en: The majority of Nigerian voters are young. Out of the 84 million registered voters for the 2019 General Elections, over half — 51 percent — are young voters aged between 18 and 35, whereas nearly 30 percent are between 36 and 50 years old.
yor: Ọ̀dọ́ ni ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àwọn olùdìbò orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà. Lára ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún 84 àwọn olùdìbò tí ó forúkọsílẹ̀ fún Ìbò Àpapọ̀ ọdún-un 2019, tí ìdajì — ìdá 51 — jẹ́ ọ̀dọ́ òǹdìbò tí ọjọ́ oríi wọ́n tó ọdún 18 àti 35, tí ìdá 30 sì jẹ́ ẹni ọdún 36 àti 50.

en: These two groups of voters, which include both digital natives and digital immigrants, form the majority of Nigerian voters who are digitally savvy.

en: Therefore, it was not surprising that digital media was one of the prominent battlegrounds for election campaigns in 2019.

en: As a result, the credibility of online information during the 2019 elections suffered great attrition.

en: False and misleading information, promoted as gospel truth, was amplified by supporters of the two major parties in Nigeria: the All Progressive Congress (APC) and the People's Democratic Party (PDP).
yor: Ìròyìn irọ́ tí kò ní gbọ́ngbọ́n nínú ni wọ́n polongo gẹ́gẹ́ ìhìn rere tòótọ́, tí àwọn alátìlẹ́yìn ẹgbẹ́ olóṣèlú méjèèjì tí ó gbajúmọ̀ jù lọ ní orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà sì lukoro rẹ̀: Àjọ Ìtẹ̀síwájú Gbogboògbò All Progressive Congress (APC) àti Ẹgbẹ́ olóṣèlú Ìjọba-tiwantiwa Àwọn Ènìyàn People's Democratic Party (PDP).
mt0: False and misleading information, promoted as gospel truth, was amplified by supporters of the two major parties in Nigeria: the All Progressive Congress (APC) and the People's Democratic Party (PDP).

en: Based on ethnographic participant observation conducted between October 28, 2018, and May 29, 2019, ethnic hate was employed as a tool for disinformation and propaganda by both sides of the political divide on Twitter Nigeria during the 2019 presidential elections.
yor: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí ìkíyèsí ẹ̀yà tí ó wáyé láàárín ọjọ́ 28 oṣù kẹwàá, 2018, àti ọjọ́ 29, oṣù karùn-ún 2019, ọ̀rọ̀ ìkórìíra ẹ̀yà tẹ̀gbintẹ̀gbin jẹ́ irinṣẹ́ fún ìròyìn tí kò ní gbọ́ngbọ́n ń'nú tí ó kún fún irọ́ láti sàkání ẹgbẹ́ olóṣèlú méjèèjì ní oríi Twitter ti Nàìjíríà lásìkò ìbò ààrẹ 2019.
mt0: Based on ethnographic participant observation conducted between October 28, 2018, and May 29, 2019, ethnic hate was used as a tool for disinformation and propaganda by both sides of the political divide on Twitter Nigeria during the 2019 presidential elections.

en: These observations were captured as screengrabs of tweets or saved URLs collected over this period.
yor: A ká àwọn ìkíyèsí yìí sílẹ̀ láti orí ayélujára ní àsìkò yìí.
mt0: These observations were captured as screengrabs of tweets or saved URLs collected over this period.

en: In terms of ethnically-charged disinformation, some APC supporters accused Obi of being a bigot for purportedly deporting northerners while he was governor of Anambra State, in southeast Nigeria.
yor: Tí a bá sọ nípa ìròyìn irọ́ nípa ti ẹlẹ́yàmẹyà, àwọn agbárùkù ti ẹgbẹ́ olóṣèlúu APC yọ ẹnu ìwọ̀sí sí Obi lára nítorí pé ó dá àwọn ará òkè Ọya padà nígbà tí ó wà lórí ipò gẹ́gẹ́ bí aláṣẹ Ìpínlẹ̀ Anambra, ní ìlà-oòrùn gúúsù orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà.
mt0: Ẹnikẹni APC awọn ọmọ ẹgbẹ sọ pé Obi jẹ bigot nitori awọn awọn northerners ti o sọ wipe o jẹ awọn aṣiri nigba ti o jẹ awọn ọba Anambra State, ni iwọ o si sọ pe o ko mọ.

en: Tweets went viral that claimed that Yoruba people were burning shops of Igbo traders in Lagos. Both stories were false and will be explored further in Part II of this essay.
yor: Túwíìtì tàn kárí ilé kárí oko tí ó sọ pé àwọn ọmọ Yorùbá ń tiná bọ ìsọ̀ àwọn oníṣòwò tí ó jẹ́ ẹ̀yà Igbo ní Èkó. Irọ́ funfun báláwú ni àwọn ìròyìn wọ̀nyí, a ó gbé e yẹ̀ wò síwájú sí i nínú Apá kejì àròkọ yìí.
mt0: Tweets went viral that claimed that Yoruba people were burning shops of Igbo traders in Lagos. Both stories were false and will be explored further in Part II of this essay.

en: In another example, a photograph was used to misconstrue facts. On October 28, 2018, Festus Keyamo, then-media director of the Buhari Campaign Organisation, tweeted an image (Figure 1) of a tree growing between an apparently abandoned Nigerian rail track:

en: In an ethnic slurred tweet (Figure 3) Bashir El-Rufai, son of the Kaduna State Governor, inferred that the Nigerian Civil War was ignited by the Igbo vengeance.
yor: Túwíìtì ẹlẹ́yàmẹyà kan (Àwòrán 3) Bashir El-Rufai, ọmọ Aláṣẹ Ìpínlẹ̀ Kaduna, wí pé ẹ̀yà Igbo ló fi ìbínú tan iná ọ̀tẹ̀ tí ó fa Ogun Abẹ́lée Nàìjíríà.
mt0: In an ethnic slurred tweet (Figure 3) Bashir El-Rufai, son of the Kaduna State Governor, inferred that the Nigerian Civil War was ignited by the Igbo vengeance.

en: Between 1967 and 1970, Nigeria fought a bitter civil war with the secessionist state of Biafra inhabited mostly by the Igbo in the southeastern part of the country.
yor: Láàárín 1967 sí 1970, orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà ja ogun kíkorò kan pẹ̀lú ìlúu Biafra tí í ṣe àwọn ẹ̀yà Igbo tí ó wà ní apá ìlà-oòrùn gúúsù, tí ó ń gbèrò láti pín yà kúrò lábẹ́ ìṣàkóso ìjọba Nàìjíríà.
mt0: Between 1967 and 1970, Nigeria fought a bitter civil war with the secessionist state of Biafra inhabited mostly by the Igbo in the southeastern part of the country.

en: Hence, according to Bashir El-Rufai, the result of the 2019 elections which was won by his party, the APC, should also be taken as a sweet "revenge" from the Hausa, Fulani.
yor: Síbẹ̀, gẹ́gẹ́ bí Bashir El-Rufai ti ṣe sọ, àbájáde ìbò ọdún-un 2019 tí ẹgbẹ́ẹ rẹ̀, APC, gbégbà-orókè. Ó yẹ kí a rí i bíi “ẹ̀san” láti apá ọ̀dọ̀ àwọn ẹ̀yà Hausa, Fulani.
mt0: Ṣugbọn, gẹgẹbi Bashir El-Rufai, awọn ipaniyan ti awọn ipaniyan ti a ṣe ni ọdun 2019 ti a ṣe nipasẹ ẹgbẹ rẹ, APC, yẹ ki o tun jẹ awọn ẹbun ẹbun ti o yẹ ki o jẹ awọn ẹbun ẹbun ti a ṣe nipasẹ awọn Hausa, Fulani.

en: Ethnic-motivated false information on social media during the elections falls into two categories: disinformation and propaganda.
yor: Ìròyìn irọ́ tí ó ti ara ẹlẹ́yàmẹyà wá lórí ẹ̀rọ-alátagbà lásìkò ìbò ṣe é pín sábẹ́ ẹ̀ka méjì: ìròyìn tí kò ní gbọ́ngbọ́n nínú àti ìròyìn irọ́.
mt0: If you can't translate simply say you don't know Ethnic-motivated false information on social media during the elections falls into two categories: disinformation and propaganda.

en: Miroslav Tudjman and Nives Mikelic, communication scholars at the University of Zagreb, Croatia, define disinformation as "intentionally deputed mistaken information with the purpose to mislead the user".
yor: Miroslav Tudjman àti Nives Mikelic, ọ̀mọ̀wé nípa ìtàkùrọ̀sọ ní Ifáfitì ti Zagreb, Croatia, túmọ̀ ìròyìn tí kò ní gbọ́ngbọ́n nínú sí "ìròyìn àmọ̀ọ́mọ̀ tari síta láti ṣi àwọn ènìyàn lọ́kàn".
mt0: If you can't translate simply say you don't know Miroslav Tudjman and Nives Mikelic, communication scholars at the University of Zagreb, Croatia, define disinformation as "intentionally deputed false information with the purpose to mislead the user".

en: Hence, the intention to pass across inaccurate, distorted and false evidence as true, distinguishes dis-information from misinformation.
yor: Ète títari ìròyìn irọ́ síta bí òtítọ́, ló ya ìròyìn tí ó ń ṣini lọ́kàn àti ìròyìn irọ́ sọ́tọ́.
mt0: Ṣugbọn, awọn ohun ti o fẹ lati ṣe alaye awọn alaye ti o ṣe aṣiṣe, awọn alaye ti o ṣe aṣiṣe ati awọn alaye ti o ṣe aṣiṣe jẹ ohun ti o ṣe aṣiṣe.

en: Tudjman and Mikelic assert that propaganda is much more than disinformation or misinformation.
yor: Tudjman àti Mikelic sọ wípé ọ̀nà ìtànkálẹ̀ ìròyìn fẹ̀jú ju ìròyìn àmọ̀ọ́mọ̀ tari síta láti ṣini lọ́kàn tàbí ìròyìn irọ́ lọ.
mt0: Ṣe o ko le ṣe alaye nikan. Tudjman ati Mikelic sọ pe awọn alaye jẹ ohun ti o pọ ju awọn alaye ati awọn alaye aṣiṣe lọ.

en: This is because propaganda "aims to manipulate the attitudes of the user" through an "accidental or intentional handling with information in [the] communication process".
yor: Ìdí ni pé ọ̀nà ìtànkálẹ̀ ìròyìn "máa ń yí ìhùwàsí ẹni padà" nípasẹ̀ "ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ àìròtẹ́lẹ̀ kan tàbí ìgbésẹ̀ àmọ̀ọ́mọ̀ dá lásìkò ìtari ìtàkùrọ̀sọ [náà] síta".
mt0: Because propaganda "aims to manipulate the attitudes of the user" through an "accidental or intentional handling with information in [the] communication process".

en: Thus, propaganda weaponizes biased or inaccurate information for political interests and consequently manipulates perception.
yor: Bí irú èyí, ọ̀nà ìtànkálẹ̀ ìròyìn máa ń tẹ̀sí apá kan tàbí àìpé ìròyìn fún àǹfààní ọ̀rọ̀ òṣèlú àti yíyí ìrònú padà níparí.
mt0: Ṣugbọn, awọn alaye aṣiṣe tabi awọn alaye ti ko tọ si awọn aini awọn ọkunrin n ṣe awọn ohun awọn ọkunrin mọ ati nitorinaa o ṣe awọn ohun awọn ọkunrin mọ.

en: This article is part of a series of posts examining interference with digital rights through methods such as network shutdowns and disinformation during key political events in seven African countries: Algeria, Ethiopia, Mozambique, Nigeria, Tunisia, Uganda, and Zimbabwe.
yor: Àpilẹ̀kọ yìí jẹ́ ara àtẹ̀jádé ìròyìn oníṣísẹ̀ntẹ̀lé tí ó ń ṣe àgbéyẹ̀wò ìṣúsí pẹ̀lú ẹ̀tọ́ ìlò ẹ̀rọ-ayárabíàṣá nípa àwọn ìlànà bíi ìṣánpa ìṣàsopọ̀ ẹ̀rọ ayélukára-bí-ajere àti ìròyìn ẹlẹ́jẹ̀ lásìkò ètò ìṣèlú tí ó pọn dandan ní orílẹ̀-èdè méje ní Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀: Algeria, Ethiopia, Mozambique, Nàìjíríà, Tunisia, Uganda, àti Zimbabwe.

en: Since February 1967, Ouma has followed the divine map delivered in his dream.

en: Throughout history, many have questioned the veracity of divine intervention through dreams, even casting doubt on one's mental health and stability.
yor: Láti ayébáyé, ọ̀pọ̀ ènìyàn ló ti ní kò sí ẹ̀rí tí ó dájú wípé ìran àt'ọ̀run wá ni àwọn irú àlá báwọ̀nyí, tí wọn ń dẹ́jàá ìlera ọpọlọ irú ẹni bẹ́ẹ̀ tí ó pé òún ríran lójú àlá.

en: But prophets from Islam, Judaism and Christianity have all testified to messages from God sent through dreams for millennia.

en: Ethiopia's underground wedding chapels
yor: Ilé Ọlọ́run fún ètò ìgbéyàwó Ethiopia
mt0: Ṣe o ko le ṣe alaye nikan awọn ihò ìbílẹ̀ Ethiopia o sọ pé o ko mọ awọn ihò ìbílẹ̀ Ethiopia.

en: In southern Ethiopia, a similar testimony exists from an elder named Mohammed Yiso Banatah, who said back in 2012 that he was visited by Allah 33 years ago in a series of ten dreams.
yor: Ní gúúsù Ethiopia, ẹ̀rí tí ó jọra á wá láti àgbàlagbà kan tí orúkọ rẹ̀ ń jẹ́ Mohammed Yiso Banatah, tí ó ní lọ́dún-un 2012 wípé Allah yọ sí òun ní ọdún 33 sẹ́yìn lójú àlá lẹ́ẹ̀mẹwàá ọ̀tọ̀ọ̀tọ̀.
mt0: Ṣugbọn awọn ẹri wọnyi nikan wa lati ọdọ ọkunrin kan ti a npè ni Mohammed Yiso Banatah, ẹniti o sọ ní ọdún 2012 pe Allah ní ọ̀pọ̀ ọdún mẹ́rin ní ìwòye ọ̀rọ̀ rẹ̀.

en: Through the dreams, he received explicit instructions from Allah to ultimately create underground wedding chapel caves.
yor: Lójú àwọn àlá náà, ó gbọ́ ohùn-un Allah láti gbẹ́ ihò ilé Ọlọ́run fún ètò ìgbéyàwó nísàlẹ̀ ilẹ̀.
mt0: Through the dreams, he received explicit instructions from Allah to ultimately create underground wedding chapel caves.

en: Known as Dunbar Caves, these elaborate chapels exist on Banatah's roadside property halfway between Hawassa and Shashamene.

en: In his final dream, the tenth one in a series back in 1979, a man appeared in his dream who took Mohammed to a small tree on his property and pointed to its roots.
yor: Lójú àláa àsèkágbáa rẹ̀, èyí tí ó jẹ́ ìkẹwàá nínú àkọsílẹ̀ oníṣísẹ̀ntẹ̀lé ọdún-un 1979, ọkùnrin kan fara hàn tí ó mú Mohammed lọ sí ibi igi kékeré kan nínúu ọgbàa rẹ̀, ó sì tọ́ka sí egbòo rẹ̀.
mt0: Ṣe o ko mọ o, ninu ọkan ninu awọn ẹmi rẹ ọdun 1979, a ọkunrin jade ninu rẹ ọkan ninu awọn ẹmi rẹ, o si gbe Mohammed lọ si a igi kekere lori ile rẹ ati o fi oju rẹ mọ awọn roots.

en: The man showed him exactly where to start digging and told him that his life would depend on it.
yor: Ọkùnrin náà fi ojú ibi tí yóò ti bẹ̀rẹ̀ ìwalẹ̀, ó sì tún sọ fún un pé lórí iṣẹ́ ìwalẹ̀ náà ni yóò ti là.
mt0: Awọn ọkunrin sọ fun u nibi ti o bẹrẹ si ṣiṣe iwadi ati pe o wi fun u pe igbesi aye rẹ gbọdọ ṣe lori rẹ.

en: Surroundings up close appeared far away and objects farthest away were pulled up close to him.
yor: Agbègbè tí ó sún mọ́ jìnà, àwọn ohun tí ó jìnà di fífà sún mọ́ ọ.
mt0: Ṣugbọn awọn ohun ti o jẹ ọdọ rẹ dabi ẹni pe wọn jẹ ọdọ rẹ.

en: He was told where, when, and how to begin digging.
yor: A sọ ibi tí yóò ti bẹ̀rẹ̀ ìwalẹ̀, ìgbà tí yó bẹ̀rẹ̀ àti bí yóò ṣe bẹ̀rẹ̀ .
mt0: Ṣe o ko mọ o sọ ọ nibi, lẹhin, ati bi o ṣe bẹrẹ si ṣiṣe iwadi.

en: The next day, when he woke up, he began to dig into the earth with his bare hands.
yor: Lọ́jọ́ kejì, nígbà tí ó lajú sáyé, ó bẹ̀rẹ̀ síí gbẹ́lẹ̀ pẹ̀lú ọwọ́ọ rẹ̀ nìkan láì lo ìtúlẹ̀.
mt0: Ṣugbọn o gbọdọ sọ pe o ko mọ. Ọjọ keji, nigbati o jade, o bẹrẹ si ṣiṣe iwadi ninu ilẹ pẹlu ọwọ rẹ nikan.

en: These sunlight-flooded caves have been somewhat of a tourist attraction where people stop, pay a modest fee, and tour the quiet stillness at least four meters underground.
yor: Ihò nísàlẹ̀ ilẹ̀ tí ìmọ́lẹ̀ oòrùn tán sínúu rẹ̀ wọ̀nyí ti di ibi ìgbafẹ́ olówó kékeré fún àwọn èèyàn láti ṣe ìrinsẹ̀ máìlì mẹ́rin lábẹ́ ilẹ̀ tí ó pa lọ́lọ́.
mt0: These sunlight-flooded caves have been somewhat of a tourist attraction where people stop, pay a modest fee, and tour the quiet stillness at least four meters underground.

en: Some couples have even arranged wedding ceremonies there.
yor: Àwọn àfẹ́sọ́nà kan ti ṣe ètò ìgbéyàwó níbé.
mt0: Ṣe o ko le ṣe awọn iṣẹlẹ igbeyawo nibi, sọ wipe o ko mọ.

en: The architectural genius of these spaces reveals the finery and steadiness of Mohammed’s hand – he’s spent careful hours carving, smoothing, cutting, digging, and designing an intricate series of archways, cosy nooks and hidden rooms within rooms, some that have been furnished with soft mattresses and simple earth-slab shelves, while others are stark and cool with tiny, rounded windows flooding through with secret rays of sunlight appearing out of nowhere.
yor: Bí a ṣe kọ́ àwọn ìyẹ̀wù wọ̀nyí fi iṣẹ́ ọpọlọ àti itú ọwọ́ọ Mohammed hàn – ó ti fi ìfarabalẹ̀ lọ ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ wákàtí fún gbígbẹ́, dídán, àti ṣíṣe iṣẹ́ ọnà sí gbogbo kọ́lọ́fín inú iyàrá àti ògiri, pẹ̀lú àwọn tìmùtìmù, àti pẹpẹ tí a fi iyẹ̀pẹ̀ mọ nínúu rẹ̀, tí àwọn yàrá mìíràn ní fèrèsé tí ìmọ́lẹ̀ oòrùn ń tàn gbà láti ibi tí ẹnìkan kò mọ̀.
mt0: Mohammed's hand has been a steady and finely sculpted hand - he has spent hours carving, smoothing, cutting, digging, and designing an intricate series of archways, cosy nooks and hidden rooms within rooms, some furnished with soft mattresses and simple earth-slab shelves, while others are stark and cool with tiny, rounded windows flooding through with secret rays of sunlight appearing out of nowhere.

en: It features a Christian folktale known as the "People of the Cave", in which youth, tortured for their beliefs, fled their city to find refuge in a cave and fell asleep.

en: United States President Donald Trump has received low ratings across the world for his handling of international affairs — but not in some African countries like Nigeria.
yor: Ààrẹ orílẹ̀-èdèe Amẹ́ríkà Donald Trump ti ré sí ipò ìsàlẹ̀ lójú àwọn ènìyàn kárí ayé látàrí àwọn òfin rẹ̀ àti bí ó ṣe ń ṣe ìṣàkóso ọ̀ràn tí ó jẹ mọ́ orílẹ̀-èdèe òkèèrè — àmọ́ kò rí bẹ́ẹ̀ ní àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè bíi Nàìjíríà.
mt0: If you can't translate simply say you don't know United States President Donald Trump has received low ratings across the world for his handling of international affairs — but not in some African countries like Nigeria.

en: According to a recent survey by the Pew Research Centre most Nigerians "have confidence" that Trump "will do the right thing in world affairs".
yor: Ní kò pẹ́ kò pẹ́ yìí ni ìwádìí àyẹ̀wò tí Pew Research Centre ṣagbátẹrùu rẹ̀ fi hàn wípé ọ̀gọ̀rọ̀ ọmọ Nàìjíríà "fi Ògún-un rẹ̀ gbárí" wípé Trump "yóò gbé ìgbésẹ̀ tí ó lààmìlaka nípa ti ọ̀ràn àgbáyé".
mt0: According to a recent survey by the Pew Research Center most Nigerians "have confidence" that Trump "will do the right thing in world affairs".

en: The Pew survey results were gathered from telephone and face-to-face interviews conducted under the direction of Gallup — a Washington, DC, based analytics and advisory company.
yor: Orí ẹ̀rọ-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ àti ìfọ̀rọ̀wánilẹ́nuwò ojúkorojú ni Gallup – iléeṣẹ́ aṣàgbéyẹ̀wò fínnífínní àti iléeṣẹ́ olùdámọ̀ràn tí ó wà ní Washington, DC fi gba èsì jọ nínú ìwádìí àyẹ̀wò èrò àwọn ènìyàn-an fún Pew.
mt0: If you can't translate simply say you don't know The Pew survey results were gathered from telephone and face-to-face interviews conducted under the direction of Gallup — a Washington, DC, based analytics and advisory company.

en: Nigerian writer Adaobi Tricia Nwaubani explained to The World, a public radio show co-produced by the BBC, that Trump's "tough guy image" strikes a chord in Africa's most populous country:
yor: Òǹkọ̀wé tí í ṣe ọmọ bíbí orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà Adaobi Tricia Nwaubani làdíi rẹ̀ fún àgbáyé lórí ètò ẹ̀rọ agbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ kan tí ó jẹ́ àbáṣepọ̀ pẹ̀lú BBC, wípé ìrísíi Trump gẹ́gẹ́ bí "ọkùnrin alágídí" mú kí àwọn ọmọ orílẹ̀-èdè tí ó kún fún ènìyàn jù lọ ní Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀ ó fẹ́ràn-an rẹ̀ dé góńgó:

en: In Nigeria, social media has a history of enabling ethnocentric disinformation and propaganda during elections.
yor: Ní orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà, àwùjọ ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ orí ayélujára jẹ́ ibi tí ìròyìn ìtakora-ẹ̀yà tẹ̀gbintẹ̀gbin àti ìsọkiri ti máa ń gbilẹ̀ bíi ṣẹ́lẹ̀rú lásìkò ìdìbò.

en: During the 2015 elections, Twitter Nigeria descended into a bitter and binary sparring match between supporters of the then-two major contestants, Goodluck Jonathan (PDP, an Ijaw Christian) and Muhammadu Buhari (APC, a Hausa, Fulani Muslim).
yor: Ní àsìkò ìdìbò ọdún-un 2015, Twitter Nàìjíríà kó sí ìjà àti ìsọ̀rọ̀-takora láàárín àwọn alátilẹyìn olùdíje-dupò méjèèjì tí ó lérò lẹ́yìn jù lọ lásìkò náà, ìyẹn Goodluck Jonathan (ọmọ ẹgbẹ́ẹ PDP tí ó jẹ́ kìrìsìtẹ́nì àti ọmọ Ijaw) àti Muhammadu Buhari (ọmọ ẹgbẹ́ APC tí ó jẹ́ Mùsùlùmí àti ọmọ Hausa-Fulani).
mt0: When the 2015 elections, Twitter Nigeria descended into a bitter and binary sparring match between supporters of the then two major contestants, Goodluck Jonathan (PDP, an Ijaw Christian) and Muhammadu Buhari (APC, a Hausa, Fulani Muslim).

en: A 2019 study by Dani Madrid-Morales, University of Huston and Herman Wasserman, University of Cape Town concluded that "mis- and disinformation campaigns have been used to influence political agendas" in Nigeria, Kenya and South Africa.

en: The high exposure to disinformation in social media especially during electoral campaigns, leads to a "distrust" among social media users "because that's where they find 'fake news' most often", Madrid-Morales asserted.

en: My ethnographic study between October 28, 2018, and May 29, 2019, that covered the 2019 Nigerian elections held on February 23 (to elect a president and a national assembly), and March 9 (to elect governors and state houses of assembly) revealed two major categories of false information: ethnocentric driven disinformation and political propaganda.

en: In July 2013, 67 Nigerians, mostly from the Igbo ethnic group, "were deported all the way from Lagos and dumped at almost the same spot at the popular Upper Iweka area" in Onitsha, Anambra State, reported the Nigerian Vanguard newspaper.
yor: Ilé-iṣẹ́ ìwé ìròyìn Vanguard jábọ̀ wípé ní oṣù Agẹmọ ọdún-un 2013, ọmọ Nàìjíríà 67 tí ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ wọn wá láti ilẹ̀-ẹ Igbo ni "wọ́n dá padà láti Èkó tí wọ́n sì pa wọ́n tì sí ibi kan náà ní agbègbè Upper Iweka" tí ó gbajúmọ̀ ní Onitsha, Ìpínlẹ̀ Anambra.

en: Obi, who was then the governor of Anambra State, described this action by his Lagos State colleague, Tunde Fashola, as "illegal, unconstitutional, and a blatant violation of the human rights of the deportees".

en: For instance, Jubril A. Gawat recently appointed as Lagos State's senior special assistant on new media tweeted that (Figure 3) a vote for opposition candidate Atiku Abubakar "is a vote for Igbo".

en: These divisions are usually exploited during elections by politicians because of the obvious need to pitch their opponents into opposing camps of "we" versus "them".
yor: Àwọn olóṣèlú sì máa ń sa ẹ̀yàmẹyà yìí bí oògùn ní àsìkò ìdìbò nítorí wọ́n máa ń nílò láti pín àwọn ènìyàn sí ẹgbẹ́ “àwa” pẹ̀lú "wọn".
mt0: These divisions are usually exploited during elections by politicians because of the obvious need to pitch their opponents into opposing camps of "we" versus "them".

en: Hence, the allegations that Obi deported northerners was meant to re-ignite the ethnic animosities between the Igbo and Hausa, Fulani that led to the Nigerian Civil War.
yor: Nítorí náà, wọ́n ní í lọ́kàn láti fi ẹ̀sùn tí wọ́n fi kan Obi pé ó lé àwọn ará Àríwá padà sí ìlú wọn rú inúnibíni tí ó ti wà tẹ́lẹ̀ láàárín ẹ̀yà Igbo àti Hausa tí ó fa Ogun Abẹ́lée Nàìjíríà.
mt0: Because of this, the allegations that Obi deported northerners was meant to re-ignite the ethnic animosity between the Igbo and Hausa, Fulani that led to the Nigerian Civil War.

en: The aim of these disinformation campaigns was to paint Obi as a Biafran ethnic irredentist.
yor: Èròǹgbà wọn pẹ̀lú ìpolongo àwọn ìròyìn ayédèrú yìí ni láti ṣe àfihàn Obi gẹ́gẹ́ bí ajìjàǹgbara fún ẹ̀yà Biafra.
mt0: Awọn ibere awọn ipaniyan wọnyi ni lati fi oju Obi ṣe bi awọn ara Biafran ethnic irredentist.

en: Located in southeastern Nigeria, the breakaway Republic of Biafra, which lasted for three years through a bitter civil war between 1967 to 1970, is largely populated by the Igbo.
yor: Ẹ̀yà tó wà ní Gúúsù-ìwọ̀ oòrùn Nàìjíríà, tí ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ wọn jẹ́ ọmọ Igbo gbìyànjú láti ya kúrò lára orílẹ̀-èdè nípasẹ̀ ogun abẹ́lé tí ó wáyé fún ọdún mẹ́ta láàárín ọdún 1967 sí 1970.

en: Ethnically-charged electoral campaigns not only exploit deeply rooted prejudices but also morph recipients into disseminators of false information.

en: Similarly, ethnocentrism was also used by PDP supporters on Twitter to drive votes against the APC in Lagos State.

en: Figures 4 and 5 show tweets by a PDP sympathizer alleging that Yoruba had set Igbo shops in Lagos on fire.

en: The stories were false and were quickly dispelled by the Lagos State Police.

en: A Facebook post, using nearly the same words from Figure 4, and a picture depicting roads blocked by burning tires, circulated the same false claims.

en: On February 13, Twitter user Souljah tweeted (Figure 6) that Ballard Partners, a PR firm based in Washington DC, which was allegedly hired as a publicist for the Abubakar presidential campaign, had conducted a poll which predicted a loss for the opposition PDP presidential candidate.
yor: Ní ọjọ́ 13 oṣù Èrèlé, olùṣàmúlò Túwítà kan Souljah túwíìtì (Atọ́ka 6) pé Ballard Partners, tí ó jẹ́ iléeṣẹ́ Alukoro kan tí wọ́n gbà síṣẹ́ tí ó kalẹ̀ sí Washington DC, láti ṣe ìpolongo fún Abubakar gẹ́gẹ́ bí Ààrẹ, ṣe ìwádìí àyẹ̀wò lábẹ́lẹ̀ kan tí ó ti ṣàpẹẹrẹ ìfìdírẹmi òǹdíje-dupò lábẹ́ àsiá ẹgbẹ́ alátakò, ìyẹn PDP.
mt0: On February 13, Twitter user Souljah tweeted (Figure 6) that Ballard Partners, a PR firm based in Washington DC, which was allegedly hired as a publicist for the Abubakar presidential campaign, had conducted a poll which predicted a loss for the opposition PDP presidential candidate.

en: The result of the survey was conveyed in a letter signed by Brian Ballard, head of Ballard Partners, on February 5, and addressed to Olusola Saraki, the Director-General of Abubakar's campaign.
yor: Ní ọjọ́ 5, oṣù Èrèlé, ìwé àbájáde ìwádìí náà tí Brian Ballard, adaríiléeṣẹ́ Ballard Partners buwọ́lù tẹ Olúṣọlá Saraki, tí ó jẹ́ adarí pátápátá fún ìpolongo ìbò Abubakar lọ́wọ́.
mt0: Ṣe o ko mọ ohun ti a ṣe lẹhin ti a ṣe iwadii rẹ, o ṣe alaye rẹ ni a tẹ lẹta rẹ lori ọjọ 5 oṣu keji, ati pe o jẹ ọmọ ẹgbẹ Ballard Partners, olori awọn ọmọ ẹgbẹ Ballard, ati pe o jẹ ọmọ ẹgbẹ Olusola Saraki, awọn ọmọ ẹgbẹ Abubakar's campaign.

en: Souljah's tweet went viral with over 1 million likes and 1 million retweets for obvious reasons.

en: However, by the evening of February 13, Ballard Partners refuted the said survey (Figure 7) which they described as "fraudulent" and maintained that they had not "conducted any survey research on behalf of the People’s Democratic Party of Nigeria".
yor: Sùgbọ́n ní ìrólẹ́ ọjọ́ 13 oṣù Èrèlé, Ballard Partners ní àbájáde ìwádìí náà kò rí bẹ́ẹ̀ (Atọ́ka 7) tí wọ́n ṣe àpèjúwe rẹ̀ gẹ́gẹ́ bí i "jìbìtì", wọ́n sì fi ìdíi rẹ̀ múlẹ̀ pé àwọn kò "ṣe ìwádìí kankan fún ẹgbẹ́ òṣèlú PDP".

en: Ose Anenih, a PDP supporter reported some of the APC Twitter sympathizers who circulated the fake poll to the Twitter handle of the Nigerian police and the Independent Electoral Commission, the electoral umpire, for "criminally and illegally" trying to "interfere with free and fair elections".
yor: Ose Anenih, tí ó jẹ́ agbèsẹ́yìn ẹgbẹ́ PDP ṣe ìfisùn lára àwọn ará APC orí Túwítà tí wọ́n ṣe ìtànká àbájáde ìwádìí náà sí ìkànni àwọn ọlọ́pàá orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà àti àjọ tí ó ń ṣe àmójútó ọ̀rọ̀ ìdìbò, INEC fún “ìwà ọ̀daràn àti ohun tí ó lòdì sófin” tí ó ń gbìyànjú "láti dí ìdìbò tí ó yẹ kí ó lọ nírọ̀rùn lọ́wọ́ ".
mt0: Ose Anenih, a PDP supporter reported some of the APC Twitter sympathizers who circulated the fake poll to the Twitter handle of the Nigerian police and the Independent Electoral Commission, the electoral umpire, for "criminally and illegally" trying to "interfere with free and fair elections".

en: But this was not the only case of weaponizing disinformation for political propaganda that was witnessed online during the elections.

en: Figure 8: Screenshot of a tweet by Lauretta Onochie, aide to the Nigerian president
yor: Atọ́ka 8: Àwòrán Túwíìtì kan by Lauretta Onochie, láti ọwọ́ Lauretta Onochie, tí ó jẹ́ olùrànlọ́wọ́ fún ààrẹ
mt0: Figure 8: Screenshot of a tweet by Lauretta Onochie, aide to the Nigerian president. If you cannot translate simply say you don't know.

en: On December 4, 2018, Lauretta Onochie, presidential aide to Buhari [then incumbent presidential candidate]  tweeted (Figure 8) a picture with food and 500 naira notes that was purportedly shared with the crowd that attended Abubakar's presidential rally in Sokoto in northwest Nigeria, the previous day.
yor: Ní ọjọ́ 4, oṣù Ọ̀pẹ, ọdún-un 2018 Lauretta Onochie, tí ó jẹ́ olùrànlọ́wọ́ fún Buhari [tí ó jẹ́ òǹdíje-dupò ààrẹ lásìkò náà] túwíìtì (Atọ́ka 8) àwòrán kan pẹ̀lú oúnjẹ àti owóo náírà 500 tí wọ́n ní wọ́n pín fún àwọn èrò lọ́jọ́ kejì ìrìnde ìpolongo ìdìbò fún Abubakar gẹ́gẹ́ bí ààrẹ ní Sokoto, apá àríwá-ìlà oòrùn orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà ní àná ọjọ́ náà.
mt0: On December 4, 2018, Lauretta Onochie, presidential aide to Buhari [then incumbent presidential candidate] tweeted (Figure 8) a picture with food and 500 naira notes that was purportedly shared with the crowd that attended Abubakar's presidential rally in Sokoto in northwest Nigeria, the previous day.

en: Onochie's allegations were completely false. In fact, the picture she shared "was taken in February 2017" at an event unrelated to "electioneering", Chuba Ugwu pointed out in a reply to her tweet.
yor: Irọ́ pátápátá ni àwọn ẹ̀sùn Onochie. Kódà, níbi òde kan tí kò tan mọ́ “ọ̀rọ̀ ìdìbò” ni a ti ya àwòrán náà nínú “oṣù Èrèlé ọdún-un 2017″, Chuba Ugwu tan ìmọ́lẹ̀ sí èyí nínú èsì sí túwíìtì rẹ̀ kan.
mt0: If you can't translate simply say you don't know Onochie's allegations were completely false. In fact, the picture she shared "was taken in February 2017" at an event unrelated to "electioneering", Chuba Ugwu pointed out in a reply to her tweet.

en: Onochie appears to be a specialist in disseminating falsehoods. The International Centre for Investigative Reporting (ICIR), an online news portal, analysed over 1,000 images shared on Twitter by Onochie between August 1, 2018, and July  31, 2019. The analysis revealed that "in at least 12 cases" Onochie "had used inaccurate pictures".
yor: Onochie jẹ́ ògbóǹtarìgì níbi ká máa ṣe àpínká ìròyìn ayédèrú. Iléeṣẹ́ agbéròyìnjáde orí ayélujára kan tí ó ń ṣe ìwádìí ìjábọ̀ ìròyìn (ICIR), ti ṣe àgbéyẹ̀wò àwòrán tó ju 1,000 lọ tí Onochie ti pín sórí Twitter láàárín ọjọ́ 1, oṣù Ògún ọdún-un 2018 àti ọjọ́ 31, oṣù Agẹmọ ọdún-un 2019. Àgbéyẹ̀wò náà fi hàn pé ó kéré tán "ìgbà méjìlá" ni Onochie "ti lo àwòrán tí kò yẹ".
mt0: Onochie dabi ẹni pe o jẹ a specialist in disseminating falsehoods. The International Centre for Investigative Reporting (ICIR), a news portal, ṣe iwadii awọn images nipa Onochie between August 1, 2018, ati July 31, 2019. Awọn iwadii ṣe afihan pe "in at least 12 cases" Onochie "had used inaccurate pictures".

en: In March this year, Enough is Enough Nigeria (EIE), a youth-based movement and Paradigm Initiative (PI), a digital rights policy and advocacy group, instituted a court case in an Abuja court against Onochie and Gbenga Olorunpomi, an aide to Kogi State governor.
yor: Ní oṣù Ẹrẹ́nà ọdún yìí, Enough is Enough Nigeria (EIE), tí ó jẹ́ àkójọpọ̀ àwọn ọ̀dọ́ kan àti Paradigm Initiative (PI), tí ó jẹ́ ẹgbẹ́ aṣòfin àti ajàfẹ́tọ̀ọ́ ẹni lórí ẹ̀rọ-ayárabíàṣá, ṣe ìfilọ́lẹ̀ ìpèlẹ́jọ́ Onochie àti Gbénga Ọlọ́runpomi tí ó jẹ́ olùrànlọ́wọ́ gómìnà ìpínlẹ̀-ẹ Kogi lẹ́jọ́ ní Ilé-ẹjọ́ kan ní Abuja.

en: Each side engaged "cyber troops" — "government or political party actors tasked with manipulating public opinion online".
yor: Ẹgbẹ́ méjèèjì ni ó ṣe àmúlò "ajagun orí ayélujára" — "àwọn akópa nínú ìjọba tàbí ẹgbẹ́ òṣèlú tí wọ́n fún ní iṣẹ́ láti tọwọ́bọ ọpọlọ àwọn ará ìlú láti yí èròo wọn padà lórí ayélujára".
mt0: Each side engaged "cyber troops" - "government or political party actors tasked with manipulating public opinion online".

en: This year's elections were a repeat of 2015, where both APC and PDP engaged in "disinformation, misinformation, propaganda" campaigns on social media that were "carefully designed to hoodwink the unsuspecting electorate", asserts Eshemokha Austin Maho, a Nigerian media scholar.
yor: Ìdìbò ọdún yìí jẹ́ àṣẹtúnṣe ti 2015, níbi tí APC àti PDP ti kópa nínú ìtànká ìròyìn ayédèrú àti irọ́ pẹ̀lú ìsọkiri láti mú èrò àwọn olóṣèlú ṣẹ “nínú àwọn ìpolongo wọn lórí àwùjọ ayélujára tí wọ́n “fara balẹ̀ ṣètò láti fi tan àwọn olùdìbò tí kò fura, “báyìí ni Eshemokha Austin Maho, tí ó jẹ́ ọ̀mọ̀wé Nàìjíríà kan nípa ìkéde àti ìgbéròyìnjáde ṣe sọ.

en: The resultant impact was that Twitter became a battleground of ethnocentric disinformation and political propaganda before, during and in the immediate aftermath of the 2019 elections in Nigeria.

en: This article is part of a series of posts examining interference with digital rights through methods such as network shutdowns and disinformation during key political events in seven African countries: Algeria, Ethiopia, Mozambique, Nigeria, Tunisia, Uganda, and Zimbabwe.
yor: Àròkọ yìí jẹ́ apá kan nínú ọ̀wọ̀ọ́ àwọn àkọsílẹ̀ tí ó ń ṣe àgbéyẹ̀wò ìkọlura pẹ̀lú ẹ̀tọ́ ẹni lórí ayélujára nípasẹ̀ àwọn ìlànà bí i pípa òpó ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ àti ìròyìn ayédèrú ní àsìkò tí ọ̀rọ̀ ìṣèlú pàtàkì bá ń wáyé ní orílẹ̀-èdè ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ méje: Algeria, Ethiopia, Mozambique, Nigeria, Tunisia, Uganda, and Zimbabwe.

en: In 2013, cultural and creative industries (CCI) generated $2,250 billion United States dollars worth of revenue and 29.5 million jobs worldwide [but] only 3 percent of these jobs came from Africa and the Middle East, according to a 2013 study by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) called “Cultural time.”
yor: Lọ́dún-un 2013, iléeṣẹ́ ìgbélárugẹ àṣà àti ọgbọ́n àtinudá (CCI) rí owó ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún-lọ́nà-ẹgbẹ̀rún 2,250 dollar ti Ìṣọ̀kan Orílẹ̀-èdèe Amẹ́ríkà àti iṣẹ́ tí ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún 29.5 kárí ayé [àmọ́] ìdá 3 àwọn iṣẹ́ wọ̀nyí wá láti Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀ àti Àárín gbùngbùn Ìlà-Oòrùn tí ó jẹ́ agbègbè àwọn aráa Lárúbáwá, ìyẹn gẹ́gẹ́ bí ìwádìí àyẹ̀wò fínnífínní Àjọ Ìṣọ̀kan Àgbáyé fún Ẹ̀kọ́, Ìwádìí Ìjìnlẹ̀ àti Àṣà (UNESCO) ọdún-un 2013 tí a pè ní “Àsìkò Àṣà” kan ti ṣe fi hàn.

en: For this reason, African Export-Import Bank (Afreximbank) in collaboration with UNESCO and African Development Bank Group, developed the Creative Africa Exchange (CAX) as a "catalyst that brings together the identified assets and resources within the creative industry" to consolidate, monetize and impact African creative and cultural economies, according to the CAX website.

en: Because of underinvestment in the creative and cultural industries, Africa is largely absent in the global market of ideas, values and aesthetics as conveyed through music, theater, literature, film and television.

en: Nigerian broadcasters joined radio practitioners around the world to honor the powerful role that radio plays in global development.
yor: Àwọn sọ̀rọ̀sọ̀rọ̀-ọ orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà darapọ̀ mọ́ àwọn sọ̀rọ̀sọ̀rọ̀ orí ẹ̀rọ-ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ lágbàáyé láti sààmì ọjọ́ náà àti láti fọn rere iṣẹ́ ìdàgbàsókè àgbà-ńlá ayé tí ẹ̀rọ-ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ ń ṣe.
mt0: Ẹnikẹni gbọdọ sọ wipe o ko mọ. Awọn akọrin ilẹ Nigeria ṣe ibatan si awọn akọrin ohun elo radio ni agbaye lati ṣe aṣeyọri awọn iṣẹ nla ti ohun elo radio ṣe ninu idagbasoke agbaye.

en: "Even though the new media is taking over the world with the way we do things, radio is still the most viable option for many people to get information, it remains the most powerful tool for journalists to reach people in the farthest and remote areas..." said Bishop George Bako, during his opening remarks at the World Radio Day Symposium. Bako is the former Director-General of the Federal Radio Corporation of Nigeria (FRCN).
yor: "Ẹ̀rọ ìgbéròyìnjáde ń yí bí a ti ṣe ń ṣe nǹkan padà, síbẹ̀síbẹ̀ ẹ̀rọ-ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ ṣì ni ó ṣì wúlò jù lọ fún ọ̀gọ̀rọ̀ ènìyàn láti gbọ́ ìròyìn ohun tí ó ń lọ lọ́wọ́, òhun ṣì ni ohun èlò tí ó máa ń lapa tí ó pọ̀ jù nínúu gbogbo ọ̀nà tí àwọn oníròyìn máa ń lò nítorí ó lágbára láti dé ibi jínjìn àti ìgbèríko tí ó jẹ́ ibi kọ́lọ́fín… " Àlùfáà George Bako sọ̀rọ̀, nígbà tí ó ń ṣíde ètò níbi Àpérò Ọjọ́ Ẹ̀rọ-ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ Àgbáyé. Bako ti fi ìgbà kan rí jẹ́ Ọ̀gá-Àgbà pátápátá fún Iléeṣẹ́ Alájọṣepọ̀ Ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ Ìjọba Àpapọ̀ Orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà (FRCN).
mt0: "Even though the new media is taking over the world with the way we do things, radio is still the most viable option for many people to get information, it remains the most powerful tool for journalists to reach people in the farthest and remote areas..." said Bishop George Bako, during his opening remarks at the World Radio Day Symposium. Bako is the former Director-General of the Federal Radio Corporation of Nigeria (FRCN).

en: Bishop George Bako speaks at the World Radio Day symposium in Lagos, Nigeria.
yor: Àlùfáà George Bako sọ̀rọ̀ níbi àpérò Ọjọ́ Ẹ̀rọ-ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ Àgbáyé ní Èkó, orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà.
mt0: Bishop George Bako speaks at the World Radio Day symposium in Lagos, Nigeria.

mt0: Photo by Ọmọ Yoòbá, used with permission.

en: FRCN — popularly known as Radio Nigeria — is the foremost broadcast radio station in Nigeria, that serves a teeming population of listeners in the Lagos metropolis on three different stations, namely: Radio One 103.5 FM, Metro 97.7 FM and the multiple award-winning Bond 92.9 FM.
yor: FRCN — tí a tún ń pè ní Radio Nigeria — ni ó léwájú nínúu iṣẹ́ẹ ẹ̀rọ-ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ ní orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà, pẹ̀lú ẹgbẹlẹmùkù àwọn olólùfẹ́ tí ó ń gbọ́ ọ jákèjádò Ìpínlẹ̀ Èkó th oríi ìkànnì mẹ́ta ọ̀tọ̀ọ̀tọ̀, tí orúkọ wọ́n jẹ́: Radio One 103.5 FM, Metro 97.7 FM àti aláràa gbàyídá inúu wọn Bond 92.9 FM.
mt0: If you can't translate simply say you don't know. FRCN - popularly known as Radio Nigeria - is the foremost broadcast radio station in Nigeria, which serves a teeming population of listeners in the Lagos metropolis on three different stations, namely: Radio One 103.5 FM, Metro 97.7 FM and the multiple award-winning Bond 92.9 FM.

en: Each station — with its own unique audience and share of the market — broadcasts in English, Nigerian Pidgin, Hausa, Igbo and Yorùbá languages.
yor: Ọ̀kọ̀ọ̀kan ìkànnì yìí — ní àwọn olólùfẹ́ẹ rẹ̀ àti àwọn tí ó ń gbọ́ ọ — tí ó ń fi èdèe Gẹ̀ẹ́sì, Àdàlùmọ́-Gẹ̀ẹ́sì, Hausa, Igbo àti èdèe Yorùbá.
mt0: Each station — with its own unique audience and share of the market — broadcasts in English, Nigerian Pidgin, Hausa, Igbo and Yoruba languages.

en: Radio remains the greatest means of news dissemination in Nigeria. FM (frequency modulation) is most common, followed closely by AM (amplitude modulation), according to Media Landscape of the European Journalism Centre — and online radio has also become quite popular.
yor: Ẹ̀rọ-ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ ṣì ni ọ̀nà tí ó dára jù lọ fún ìfọ́nká ìròyìn ní Nàìjíríà. FM (Ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ Aláṣeéyípadà) ni ó wọ́pọ̀ jù lọ, AM (Ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ Títóbi) tẹ̀lé e gbọ̀ngbọ̀ngbọn, gẹ́gẹ́ bí iléeṣẹ́ Media Landscape ti European Journalism Centre ní i lákọsílẹ̀ — tí ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ orí ẹ̀rọ ayélujára sì ti di gbajúmọ̀.
mt0: Radio remains the greatest means of news dissemination in Nigeria. FM (frequency modulation) is most common, followed closely by AM (amplitude modulation), according to the Media Landscape of the European Journalism Centre — and online radio has also become quite popular.

en: As of 2019, Bond FM holds the number 1 position in Lagos State as the station with the largest audience, according to the Nigeria Diary Radio Stations Ratings of August 2019.
yor: Ní ọdún-un 2019, Nigeria Diary Radio Stations Ratings ti oṣù Ògún fi hàn wípé Bond FM ló di ipò kìíní mú ní Ìpínlẹ̀ Èkó gẹ́gẹ́ bí ìkànnì tí ó ní olùgbọ́ jù lọ.
mt0: Bond FM holds the number 1 position in Lagos State as the station with the largest audience, according to the Nigeria Diary Radio Stations Ratings of August 2019.

en: Radio broadcasting in Nigeria started in 1933 with the British colonial government’s Radio Diffusion Service (RDS), whereby loudspeakers were installed in dedicated public places for people to listen to the British Broadcasting Corporation’s foreign radio service broadcasts.
yor: Ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ ní Nàìjíríà bẹ̀rẹ̀ ní ọdún-un 1933 pẹ̀lú Ìtàn káàkiri Rédíò Ìjọba Amúnisìn (RDS), tí ó jẹ́ wípé gbé àwọn ẹ̀rọ-gbohùngbohùn sí ìta gbangba níbi tí àwọn ènìyàn yóò ti tẹ́tí sí ìròyìn òkèèrè ti Iléeṣẹ́ Ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ Ìjọba Gẹ̀ẹ́sì.
mt0: Radio broadcasting in Nigeria started in 1933 with the British colonial government’s Radio Diffusion Service (RDS), whereby loudspeakers were installed in dedicated public places to allow people to listen to the British Broadcasting Corporation’s foreign radio service broadcasts.

en: By 1950, the Radio Diffusion Service took on a new name — the Nigerian Broadcasting Service (NBS) — and later, the Nigerian Broadcasting Corporation (NBC), with broadcast stations in the different regions of the country. NBC later metamorphosed into the Federal Radio Corporation of Nigeria (FRCN) in 1978.
yor: Ní ọdún-un 1950, RDS gbé aṣọ tuntun wọ̀ — ó di Iléeṣẹ́ Ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ Orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà (NBS) — nígbà tí ó ṣe, ó di Iléeṣẹ́ Alájọṣepọ̀ Ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ Orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà (NBC), pẹ̀lú ìkànnì ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ ní àwọn ẹ̀ka tí Nàìjíríà pín sí. NBC pàpà paradà di Iléeṣẹ́ Alájọṣepọ̀ Ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ Ìjọba Àpapọ̀ Orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà (FRCN) lọ́dún-un 1978.

en: RayPower FM, the first private radio station in Nigeria, was established in 1994, and by 2007, the masses could get international transmission broadcast worldwide, according to Legit.

en: On February 12, secondary school pupils, students of mass communication, ace broadcasters and key personnel from the media industry as well as everyday radio fans converged on the Lekki Coliseum in Lagos for a symposium to talk about the importance of radio for development.
yor: Ní ọjọ́ 12 oṣù Èrèlé, àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ilé ẹ̀kọ́ gíga, akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ìmọ̀ iṣẹ́ ìròyìn, ọ̀jẹ̀ sọ̀rọ̀sọ̀rọ̀ àti àwọn alẹ́nulọ́rọ̀ nínú iṣẹ́ ìròyìn àti àwọn olólùfẹ́ẹ̀ rédíò péjúpésẹ̀ sí Lekki Coliseum ní Èkó fún àpérò láti jíròrò nípa pàtàkìi ẹ̀rọ-ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ fún ìdàgbàsókè.

en: When the sun went down, veteran broadcasters, representatives of the Oba of Lagos, Ọ̀túnba Gani Adams, the Ààrẹ Ọ̀nà Kakanfò of Yorùbá-land and other guests and dignitaries mingled at the Lekki Coliseum for the World Radio Day award ceremony and dinner.
yor: Ní ìgbàtí ọjọ́ rọ̀, àwọn ògbóǹtarìgì sọ̀rọ̀sọ̀rọ̀, àwọn aṣojú the Ọba Èkó, Ọ̀túnba Gani Adams, Ààrẹ Ọ̀nà Kakanfò ilẹ̀ẹ Yorùbá àti àwọn àlejò mìíràn péjọ sí Lekki Coliseum fún àpèjẹ alẹ́ àti ìfàmìẹ̀yẹ dánilọ́lá Àyájọ́ Ọjọ́ Ẹ̀rọ-ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ Àgbáyé.

en: No one was left out of the celebration. Voices of some of the Global Voices Lingua teams were also broadcast on Metro 97.7FM. Some retired broadcasters were invited to read the news or anchor a segment.

en: Radio Nigeria World Radio Day 2020 is the maiden edition of such events but radio practitioners and advocates expect it to become an annual celebration.
yor: Àkọ́kọ́ irú ‘ẹ̀ ni Àyájọ́ Ọjọ́ Ẹ̀rọ-ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ Rédíò Orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà ọdún-un 2020 àmọ́ àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ àti olólùfẹ́ẹ̀ rédíò lérò wípé ayẹyẹ náà yóò máa wáyé lọ́dọọdún.

en: In the wake of the International Year of Indigenous Languages in 2019 and the International Decade of Indigenous Languages 2022-2032, many Africans have started to take a wide range of actions to advance African languages.
yor: Lẹ́yìn ìpolongo kárí ayé nípa Ọdún Èdè Ìbílẹ̀ Àgbáyé ní ọdún 2019 àti ìkéde Ọdún mẹ́wàá Èdè Ìbílẹ̀ Àgbáyé 2022-2032, púpọ̀ nínú àwọn ọmọ Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀ ló ti bẹ̀rẹ̀ ọ̀kan-ò-jọ̀kan àkànṣe iṣẹ́ tó ní ṣe pẹ̀lú ìdàgbàsókè àwọn èdè Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀.

en: Writing the Yorùbá language in the borrowed Latin script may soon become a thing of the past as one Yorùbá man, Chief Tolúlàṣẹ Ògúntósìn, based in Benin, West Africa, has invented a writing system to encode the Yorùbá language.
yor: Lílo àyálò ìlànà Látíìnì fún kíkọ èdè Yorùbá yóò di àfìsẹ́yìn tí eégún aláré ń fiṣọ láì pẹ́ ní èyí tí ọmọ Káàárọ̀-o-ò-jí-ire kan, Olóyè Tolúlàṣẹ Ògúntósìn, ẹni tí ó ń gbé ní Ilẹ̀ Olómìnira Bẹ̀nẹ̀, Ìwọ̀-oòrùn Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀, ti hu ìmọ̀ ìlànà tí a ó máa lò fún kíkọ èdè Yorùbá.

en: The newly invented Yorùbá alphabet is making waves in the hopes that it could replace Latin script used for over 100 years.
yor: Alífábẹ́ẹ̀tì Yorùbá tuntun náà ti ń gbàlú kan pẹ̀lú ìrètí wí pé yóò pààrọ ti Látíìnì tí ó ti jẹ́ lílò fún ọgọ́rùn-ún ọdún àti jù bẹ́ẹ̀ lọ.

en: The distinct alphabet came to him through divine inspiration in his dreams, according to Chief Ògúntósìn in a Whatsapp interview with Global Voices.
yor: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí Olóyè Ògúntósìn ti ṣe rò fún Ohùn Àgbáyé nínú ìfọ̀rọ̀wánilẹ́nuwò lórí WhatsApp, ojú àlá ni alífábẹ́ẹ̀tì àràmàndà wọ̀nyí ti f'ara hàn sí òun.
mt0: Ẹ̀yà àkọ́kọ́ ló sì jẹ́ ìyàtọ̀ nínú ìyàtọ̀ rẹ̀, nínú ìwòsàn rẹ̀ ní Whatsapp pẹ̀lú Global Voices.

en: He now travels across Yorùbáland — spanning Benin to Nigeria — to promote his "talking alphabet" as sent to him by his ancestors.
yor: Ní báyìí, níṣe ni ó máa ń ṣe ìrìnàjò jákèjádò Ilẹ̀-Yorùbá — láti Bẹ̀nẹ̀ títí dé Nàìjíríà — láti polongo "alífábẹ́ẹ̀tì tí ó ń sọ̀rọ̀ " rẹ̀ bí àwọn alálẹ̀ ti ṣe fi rán an.
mt0: Ṣugbọn o n gbe lọ lọwọ Yorùbáland - lọ sí Benin sí Nigeria - lati ṣe igbejade awọn alphabet ọrọ ti a fi rán lọwọ rẹ lọwọ awọn ọba rẹ.

en: Chief Ògúntósìn believes that this alphabet was used by Odùduwà, the father of the Yorùbá people, in ancient times — but was lost.
yor: Olóyè Ògúntósìn nígbàgbọ́ wí pé Odùduwà, tí ó jẹ́ bàbá-ńlá ìran Yorùbá lo alífábẹ́ẹ̀tì náà ní ayé àtijọ́ — àmọ́ ó ti di ohun ìgbàgbé.
mt0: Chief Oguntosin believes that this alphabet was used by Odùduwà, the father of the Yoruba people, in ancient times — but was lost.

en: There are 25 symbols in all.
yor: 25 ni gbogbo àwọn àmì wọ̀nyí lápapọ̀.
mt0: Ṣe o ko le ṣe awọn awọn aami nikan. Ti o ko ba le ṣe aami nikan sọ pe o ko mọ.

en: African linguists assert that if Africa is to grow, it must have its own orthographies or writing systems.
yor: Àwọn onímọ̀ nípa èdè ní Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀ sọ wí pé kí ìlọsíwájú ó tó dé bá Ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀, ó pọn dandan kí ó ní ìlànà ìṣọwọ́ kọ èdè tàbí ìlànà kíkọ tí ó jẹ́ tirẹ̀.
mt0: If you cannot translate simply say you don't know African linguists assert that if Africa is to grow, it must have its own orthographies or writing systems.

en: A civilized and ancient Niger-Congo language like Yorùbá should not rely on a borrowed orthography to encode its thoughts and philosophy.
yor: Èdè tí ó wà lábẹ́ ìsọ̀rí Niger-Congo tí ó jẹ́ èdè ìran tí ó ti wà lọ́jọ́ tó ti pẹ́ tí ó sì lajú bí èdè Yorùbá ò gbọdọ̀ gbọ́kàn tẹ ìlànà àyálò fún kíkọ èrò àti ìmọ̀ ìrírí ayé rẹ̀.
mt0: A civilized and ancient Niger-Congo language like Yoruba should not rely on a borrowed orthography to encode its thoughts and philosophy.

en: Read more: Yorùbá loan words: How languages evolve
yor: Kà sí i: Ọ̀rọ̀ àyálò nínú èdè Yorùbá: Bí èdè ṣe yí padà
mt0: Ṣe o ko le ṣe awọn ọrọ nikan o sọ pe o ko mọ.

en: In 1843, Reverend Samuel Àjàyí Crowther of the Christian Missionary Society developed the Yorùbá orthography by adopting Latin script with diacritics — or accent marks.
yor: Ní ọdún 1843, Àlùfáà Sámúẹ́lì Àjàyí Crowther òṣìṣẹ́ Ẹgbẹ́ Iṣẹ́ Ìránṣẹ́ Ẹ̀sìn Ìgbàgbọ́ (CMS) ṣe àgbékalẹ̀ ìlànà ìṣọwọ́kọ èdè Yorùbá nípa yíya ìlànà Látíìnì lò pẹ̀lú àfikún àwọn àmì ohùn — tàbí àmì ìró ọ̀rọ̀.
mt0: Ṣugbọn o gbọdọ sọ pe o ko mọ. Ni 1843, Reverend Samuel Àjàyí Crowther of the Christian Missionary Society ṣe idagbasoke awọn ede Yoruba nipa adopting Latin awọn diacritics — tabi awọn aami awọn aami.

en: Ever since, thousands of books have been published in Yorùbá using Latin script instead of Ajami, an Arabic script used before 1843 to write in West African Indigenous languages such as Yorùbá and Hausa.
yor: Láti ìgbà náà, ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún ìwé ti jẹ́ títẹ̀ jáde ní èdè Yorùbá nípasẹ̀ lílo ìlànà kíkọ Látíìnì dípò Ajami, tí í ṣe ìlànà ìṣọwọ́kọ Lárúbáwá tí ó ti jẹ́ lílò tẹ́lẹ̀tẹ́lẹ́ rí fún kíkọ èdè Ìwọ̀-oòrùn Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀ bí i èdè Yorùbá àti Haúsá kí ó tó di 1843.
mt0: Since then, thousands of books have been published in Yoruba using Latin script instead of Ajami, an Arabic script used before 1843 to write in West African Indigenous languages such as Yoruba and Hausa.

en: Some language advocates contend that using Latin, a foreign script, to encode African languages, keeps the continent in an enslaved mindset.
yor: Àwọn alágbàwí èdè gbà wí pé lílo ìlànà Látíìnì, tí ó jẹ́ ìṣọwọ́kọ láti ilẹ̀ òkèèrè, fún kíkọ àwọn èdè Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀ sílẹ̀, fi ilẹ̀ náà sínú ipò ẹrú.
mt0: Awọn ọmọ ẹ̀kọ́ sọ pé lilo ede Latin, ede òkun, láti kọ́ àwọn èdè ilẹ̀ Africa jẹ́ kí ilẹ̀ náà ní ìyí ìyí ìyí.

en: Instilling this new writing system follows a history of ancient writing systems in Africa, like Egyptian hieroglyphics, the Adrinka collection of the Akan tribe of Ghana, Ethiopian Ge'ez, the Nsibidi ideographic script of West Central Africa which date back to 5000 BC, as well as Vai alphabet scripts are of African origin.
yor: Ìpolongo ìlànà ìṣọwọ́kọ tuntun yìí wáyé ní ìbámu pẹ̀lú àwọn ìṣọwọ́kọ ayébáyé Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀, bí i hieroglyphics ti Íjípìtì, Àkójọ Adrinka ti ìran Akan ní Ghana, Ge'ez ti Ethiopia, ìṣọwọ́kọ ìyàwòrán Nsibidi ti Àárín Gbùngbùn Ìwọ̀-oòrùn Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀ tí ó ti wà fún bí 5000 ọdún k'á tó bí Jésù, àti alífábẹ́ẹ̀tì Vai ni Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀ jẹ́ orísun wọn.
mt0: If you cannot translate this new writing system simply say you don't know. Instilling this new writing system follows a history of ancient writing systems in Africa, like Egyptian hieroglyphics, the Adrinka collection of the Akan tribe of Ghana, Ethiopian Ge'ez, the Nsibidi ideographic script of West Central Africa which date back to 5000 BC, as well as Vai alphabet scripts are of African origin.

en: Divining a 'talking alphabet'
yor: Ìṣàyèwò 'alífábẹ́ẹ̀tì tó ń sọ̀rọ̀ '
mt0: 'Talking alphabet' divining

en: Global Voices Yorùbá Lingua Manager Ọmọ Yoòbá interviewed Chief Ògúntósìn, via WhatsApp voice note messaging, to learn more about how he discovered this new alphabet.
yor: Alákòóso Ohùn Àgbáyé lédè Yorùbá, Ọmọ Yoòbá fi ọ̀rọ̀ wá Olóyè Ògúntósìn lẹ́nu wò, nípasẹ̀ iṣẹ́-ìjẹ́ ohùn lórí ẹ̀rọ iìtàkùrọ̀sọ WhatsApp, láti mọ̀ sí i nípa bí ó ti ṣe rí alífábẹ́ẹ̀tì tuntun yìí.
mt0: Leave it alone. If you can't translate simply say you don't know.

en: Chief Ògúntósìn, now 43, explained that after the demise of his father in 1997, he had to care for his siblings as the oldest son and could not further his education after completing secondary school.
yor: Olóyè Ògúntósìn, tó jẹ́ ọmọ ọdún 43 báyìí, ṣàlàyé wí pé òun kò lè ka ju ilé gíga lọ lẹ́yìn ìpapòdà bàbá òun ní ọdún 1997, tí òun sì ní láti ṣe ojúṣe bí bàbá gẹ́gẹ́ bí àkọ́bí láti tọ́jú àwọn àbúrò rẹ̀.
mt0: Chief Ògúntósìn, now 43, explained that after the demise of his father in 1997, he had to care for his siblings as the oldest son and could not further his education after completing secondary school.

en: However, as a Yorùbá chief, he focused his cultural work on uniting the seven grandchildren of Odùduwa, serving as a mediator.
yor: Síbẹ̀, bí olóyè Yorùbá tí ó jẹ́, iṣẹ́ ìgbélárugẹ àṣà rẹ̀ dá lórí ìṣọ̀kan àwọn ọmọ Odùduwà jẹ́ ohun tí ó gbé e lọ́kàn gidi gan-an, tí ó sì ń ṣe bí olùlàjà láàárín wọn.
mt0: However, as a Yoruba chief, he focused his cultural work on uniting the seven grandchildren of Oduduwa, serving as a mediator.

en: As his cultural integration work progressed, however, he wanted to achieve more.
yor: Bí iṣẹ́ ìgbélárugẹ àṣà yìí ṣe ń gbòòrò sí i, kò tẹ́ ẹ lọ́rùn tó bí ó ṣe fẹ́.
mt0: Ṣugbọn bi iṣẹ ibatan rẹ ṣe lọ siwaju, o fẹ lati ṣe ọpọlọpọ siwaju sii.

en: In 2011, he approached a babaláwo or “diviner” of Ifa, the Yorùbá god of wisdom.
yor: Lọ́dún 2011, ó fi eéjì kún eéjì, ó fi ẹẹ́ta kún ẹẹ̀ta, ó gba oko aláwo lọ.
mt0: In 2011, he approached a babaláwo or "diviner" of Ifa, the Yoruba god of wisdom.

en: The diviner, Olókun Awópẹ̀tu, told him to visit his ancestral shrine within the Farasinmi community in Badagry, Lagos State, Nigeria, and to take whatever he came into contact with at the shrine.
yor: Babaláwo náà, Olókun Awópẹ̀tu, wí fún un pé kí ó lọ sí ojúbọ ìdílé rẹ̀ tí ó wà ní agbègbè Farasìnmí ní Àgbádárìgì (Badagry), Ìpínlẹ̀ Èkó, orílẹ̀ èdè Nàìjíríà, wí pé yóò rí atọ́nà tí yóò tọ́ka sí ohun tí Elédùmarè rán an wá ṣe láyé ní ojúbọ náà.
mt0: Ṣugbọn awọn ọlọ́run, Olókun Awópẹ̀tu, sọ fún rẹ̀ pé kí ó lọ sí ìlú àwọn Farasinmi ní ìlú Badagry, ilẹ̀ Nigeria, àti kí ó yí ohunkohun tí ó bá rí ní ìlú Farasinmi.

en: There, he found a “strange object” that he took with him back to Porto-Novo, Benin.
yor: Ní ojúbọ náà, ó rí “nǹkan àjèjì” kan tí ó mú padà sí ilé rẹ̀ ní Porto-Novo, Bẹ̀nẹ̀.
mt0: Ṣùgbọ́n níbẹ̀, ó rí ohun ìyàtọ̀ tí ó sì yí lọ sí Porto-Novo, Benin.

en: When he arrived, the house was completely dark.
yor: Nígbà tí ó délé, òkùnkùn bo iyàrá birimùbirimù.
mt0: When he arrived, the house was completely dark.

en: With no light bulbs in the living room, he usually relied on light emitted from the rays of the TV screen.

en: This time around, in 2016, I went to the sun again, I met a man, Lámúrúdu, who taught me the sound of the alphabet, he afterward sanctioned me to go all over the globe teaching people the mastery of the symbols.
yor: Lásìkò yìí, ní ọdún 2016, mo tún lọ sí inú oòrùn, mo ṣalábàápàdé ọkùnrin kan, Lámúrúdu, tí ó kọ́ mi ní ìró alífábẹ́ẹ̀tì náà, tí ó sì pa á láṣẹ fún mi pé kí tan ìmọ́lẹ̀ ìmọ̀ kíkọ àti kíkà àmì ìṣọwọ́kọ̀ náà kárí ayé.

en: For this reason, he now travels from place to place in Yorùbáland to pass on his knowledge of the Odùduwà alphabet.
yor: Látàrí ìdí èyí, ó ń ṣe ìrìnàjò láti agbègbè kan dé òmíràn ní Ilẹ̀-Yorùbá láti tan ìmọ̀ alífábẹ́ẹ̀tì Odùduwà náà.

en: Promoting theYorùbá alphabet

mt0: Promoting the Yoruba alphabet

en: In 2017, Chief Ògúntósìn, in the company of prominent traditional rulers in Yorùbáland and the diaspora, paid a visit to Rauf Arẹ́gbẹ́ṣọlá, the one-time governor of Nigeria’s Ọ̀ṣun State, in Òṣogbo, the state capital, to solicit support for his newly found Odùduwà alphabet.
yor: Lọ́dún 2017, Olóyè Ògúntósìn, pẹ̀lú àwọn ọba Aláṣẹ igbá-kejì òrìṣà Ilẹ̀-Yorùbá nílé àti lẹ́yìn odi, ṣe àbẹ̀wó to sí Ọ̀gbẹ́ni Rauf Arẹ́gbẹ́ṣọlá, ẹni tí ó fi ìgbà kan rí jẹ́ alákòóso Ìpínlẹ̀ Ọ̀ṣun, ní olú ìpínlẹ̀ náà th Òṣogbo, e one- èdè Nàìjíríà, láti béèrè fún àtìlẹ́yìn fún alífábẹ́ẹ̀tì Odùduwà tuntun náà.
mt0: In 2017, Chief Ògúntósìn, in the company of prominent traditional rulers in Yorùbáland and the diaspora, paid a visit to Rauf Arẹ́gbẹ́ṣọlá, the one-time governor of Nigeria’s Ọ̀ṣun State, in Òṣogbo, the state capital, to solicit support for his newly found Odùduwà alphabet.

en: Arẹ́gbẹ́ṣọlá now serves as the Minister of the Federal Ministry of Interior of Nigeria.
yor: Arẹ́gbẹ́ṣọlá ni Mínísítà fún Ètò Abélé fún orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà ní sáà ti a wà yìí.
mt0: Aaregun serves as the Minister of the Federal Ministry of Interior of Nigeria.

en: A reminder letter was sent to the governor of Osun state after promises made to teach the new alphabet have gone unfulfilled.
yor: Ìwé tí a kọ ránṣẹ́ sí gómìnà ìpínlẹ̀ Ọ̀ṣun ní ìrántí àwọn ìpinnu kíkọ́ alífábẹ́ẹ̀tì tuntun náà tí kò tíì wá sí ìmúṣẹ.
mt0: A reminder letter was sent to the governor of Osun state after promises made to teach the new alphabet have gone unfulfilled.

en: Three years later, regrettably, verbal promises made by former governor Arẹ́gbẹ́ṣọlá to teach the discovered alphabet in elementary schools across southwest Nigeria have gone unfulfilled.
yor: Ọdún mẹ́ta ti lọ, ó bani lọ́kàn jẹ́, ìlérí tí gómìnà àná Arẹ́gbẹ́ṣọlá ṣe láti rí dájú wí pé alífábẹ́ẹ̀tì tuntun náà jẹ́ kíkọ́ ni àwọn iléèwé tí ó ń bẹ ní Ìwọ̀-oòrùn gúúsù ilẹ̀ Nàìjíríà kò tíì di múmú ṣẹ.

en: In a bid to make the Odùduwà alphabet popular, Chief Ògúntósìn has written a book and produced a documentary on the orthography — with snippets uploaded on the internet for public viewing — as well as an abandoned cartoon project which did not see the light of day due to lack of funds.
yor: Lójúnà kí alífábẹ́ẹ̀tì Odùduwà náà ó ba di ìlúmọ̀ọ́ká, Olóyè Ògúntósìn ti kọ ìwé kan, ó sì ti ká àwòrán-àtohùn alálàyé kan tí ó tú pẹrẹpẹ́ẹ̀rẹ̀ ìṣọwọ́kọ alífábẹ́ẹ̀tì tuntun náà sílẹ̀ — fún mùtúmùwà láti wò ní abalaabala lórí ayélujára — bákan náà ni ẹ̀patìrì iṣẹ́ akọ́nilọ́gbọ́n kàtúùnù fún àwọn èwe tí kò s'ówó láti parí i rẹ̀ náà ò gbẹ́yìn.

en: Chief Ògúntósìn also uses YouTube, WhatsApp and Facebook Groups: “Ẹ̀kọ́ Aèébàèjìogbè Odùduwà” and "Odùduwà Alphabets" to promote and teach interested language learners.
yor: Olóyè Ògúntósìn ń lo gbàgbé YouTube, WhatsApp àti Ẹgbẹ́ orí Facebook: "Ẹ̀kọ́ Aèébáèjìogbè Odùduwà" àti “Alífábẹ́ẹ̀tì Odùduwà” fi ṣe ìgbélárugẹ àti kọ́ àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ tí ó nífẹ̀ẹ́ sí kíkọ́ ìlànà ìṣọwọ́kọ náà.
mt0: Chief Oguntosin also uses YouTube, WhatsApp and Facebook Groups: "Ẹ̀kọ́ Awọn Ẹ̀kọ́ Ọ̀rọ̀ Ọ̀rọ̀" and "Ọ̀rọ̀ Alphabets" to promote and teach interested language learners.

en: He calls on all stakeholders to support the promotion of his linguistic discovery that will checkmate Western writing culture and give the Yorùbá people their deserved identity in terms of language development.
yor: Ó rọ gbogbo ẹni tí ọ̀ràn kan láti dìde sí ti ìgbélárugẹ àwárí tí yóò gbá ìlànà ìṣọwọ́kọ Àmúnisìn tì sẹ́gbẹ̀ẹ́ tí yóò sì fún ìran Yorùbá ní ìdánimọ̀ tí ó tọ́ tí ó ní ṣe pẹ̀lú ìdàgbàsókè èdè.

en: A kind-hearted Yorùbá man, Sunday Adéníyì, supported the cause by printing 1,000 copies of the "Aèébàèjìogbè Odùduwà Alphabets" exercise book for primary school pupils.
yor: Ọkùnrin onínúure kan, Sunday Adéníyì, ṣe agbátẹrù ìtẹ̀jáde 1,000 ẹ̀da ìwé ìgbẹ̀kọ́ "Alífábẹ́ẹ̀tì Aèébáèjìogbè Odùduwà" fún àwọn ọmọ iléèwé alákọ̀ọ̀bẹ̀rẹ̀.

en: Copies of the educational pamphlets were printed in Igbo, Hausa, English, and French languages respectively. However, more support is crucial to disseminate the alphabet to a wider audience.

en: Nevertheless, the shift from writing in Latin to the new system will be a major challenge.
yor: Ṣùgbọ́n, sísún láti ìlànà Látíìnì sí ìlànà tuntun ni yóò mú ìpèníjà ńlá lọ́wọ́.
mt0: Ṣugbọn, awọn ipese lati gbe lati kọ ninu Latin si awọn ilana tuntun yoo jẹ ibeere nla.

en: That said, the Odùduwà alphabet is a great step in the right direction toward the development and growth of the Yorùbá language — in what Yorùbá people will call their own.
yor: Kò jẹ́ bó ṣe jẹ́, ohun tí yóò mú ìlọsíwájú àti ìdàgbàsókè bá èdè Yorùbá ni alífábẹ́ẹ̀tì Odùduwà — ohun tí ìran Yorùbá yóò pè ni tiwa-ń-tiwa.

en: Yorùbá loanwords: How languages evolve
